p.text:
The appellant ('the Employee') was dismissed by the second respondent, the Malaysian Co-operative Consumer Society Ltd ('the Employer') after two years of employment. The Employee made a representation to the Director General for Industrial Relations under
s 20(1) of the Industrial Relations Act 1967 ('the Act') claiming that he was dismissed by the Employer without just cause or excuse and asking that he be reinstated to his former post, failing which he should be entitled to reasonable compensation for loss of earnings and loss of substantial gratuity, higher rates of the Employees' Provident Fund, deprivation of housing loan and other benefits. His representation was referred to the Industrial Court, which subsequently held that the Employee was dismissed with just cause or excuse. The Employee applied to the High Court for Judicial Review on various grounds appearing in his affidavit in support, which appear sufficently in the judgments of the Federal Court but his application was dismissed. The Employee then appealed to the Federal Court against the decision of the High Court. Broadly stated, the questions of law for the determination of the Federal Court were: (i) whether the Award of the Industrial Court should be quashed; and (ii) if so, whether in the particular circumstances of this case the Federal Court had the power not merely to quash the Award of the Industrial Court and remit the case to the Industrial Court to hear and determine the same according to law, but to go further and itself find that the Employee had been dismissed from service without just cause or excuse, and to award fair compensation.
Held , allowing the Employee's appeal:

(Per Eusoff Chin Chief Justice ) There was prima facie evidence that the reasons given for the termination of the Employee's services in the Employer's letter dated 20 April 1988 were not genuine and that the purported termination was mala fide. The Industrial Court in its Award did not at all address its mind to the issue of bias raised by the Employee which, in the Court's view, was the central pillar of his case. The failure of the Industrial Court to address its mind to this fundamental issue was a serious error which affected jurisdiction and which resulted in the Award being quashed (see p 177F, H).

(Per Eusoff Chin Chief Justice ) It is trite law that a party is bound by its pleadings. The Industrial Court must scrutinize the pleadings and identify the issues, take evidence, hear the parties' arguments and finally pronounce its judgment having strict regard to the issues. The Industrial Court cannot ignore the pleadings and treat them as mere pedantry or formalism, because if it does so, it may lose sight of the issues, admit evidence irrelevant to the issues or reject evidence relevant to the issues and come to the wrong conclusion. In this case, the Industrial Court had totally failed to consider the allegations of misconduct but simply concluded that because the letter of termination was grounded on retrenchment exercise, it was not bound and therefore not obliged to consider the issues of bias and misconduct (see p 178B—D).

(Per Eusoff Chin Chief Justice ) There is no provision in the
Courts of Judicature Act 1964 ('the CJA'), the
Rules of the High Court 1980 ('the RHC') or the Act expressly or impliedly prohibiting the High Court from granting any relief as provided for in the Act when quashing an Award of the Industrial Court. The court cannot override an express provision of the law, but if there is no express provision in the statute, then the court can exercise its powers in a suitable case (see p 181I); Zainal Abidin v Century Hotel
[1982] 1 MLJ 260
followed.

(Per Eusoff Chin Chief Justice ) Section 33B of the Act provides that an Award of the Industrial Court shall be final and conclusive and shall not be challenged, appealed against, reviewed, quashed or called in question in any court of law. Yet, our High Courts and Federal Court intervene to quash the Awards of the Industrial Court in appropriate cases, all for the cause of justice. Therefore, even when the statute declares an Award is final, the Court can still intervene (see p 182I); Sungai Wangi Estate v Uni
[1975] 1 MLJ 136
; Minister of Labour, Malaysia v National Union of Journalists, Malaysia
[1991] 1 MLJ 24
followed.

(Per Eusoff Chin Chief Justice ) It was clear that the High Courts and the Federal Court have adopted a liberal and progressive approach in certiorari proceedings. Where the particular facts of the case warrant it, the High Court should endeavour to remedy an injustice when it is brought to its notice rather than deny relief to an aggrieved party on purely technical and narrow grounds. The High Court should mould the relief in accordance with the demands of justice (see p 183C); Sungai Wangi Estate v Uni
[1975] 1 MLJ 136
; Minister of Labour, Malaysia v National Union of Journalists, Malaysia
[1991] 1 MLJ 24
followed.

(Per Eusoff Chin Chief Justice ) Section 30(3) of the Act requires the Industrial Court to make its Award without delay and where practicable within 30 days. Here, the Employee had been without a job for seven years, and the object and spirit of the Act to have industrial disputes speedily resolved in the national interests had been defeated and frustrated. The courts, therefore, should not be obliged to continue to arrive at decisions which are both unjust to the citizens and inimical to the public well-being simply because of something decided centuries ago (see p 184D, F).

(Per Eusoff Chin Chief Justice ) Based on the facts on record, this was a fit and proper case where the jurisdiction of the Court should not end with the quashing of the Award. The High Court jurisdiction should not be curtailed or narrowed or constricted by mere reference to the old historical development in which the writ of certiorari was developed and came to be granted by the courts in England. If the application for certiorari is dismissed, that ends the matter. But if the application is allowed, the Court has surely to mould the order. If it were to merely grant certiorari to quash the Award and nothing more, this would deprive the writ of its vital and effective meaning and may result in grave injustice being caused to the Employee (see p 184F—H).

(Per Eusoff Chin Chief Justice ) As far as possible, the anxiety and endeavour of the Court should be to remedy an injustice when it is brought to its attention. On the facts of the case before the court, to remit this matter back to the Industrial Court would mean prolonging the dispute, which would hardly be fair or conducive to the interests of the parties. In the circumstances, justice demanded that to avoid further delay and expense, the Court should determine the consequential relief rather than remit the case to the Industrial Court for that purpose (see pp 184I and 185A).

(Per Eusoff Chin Chief Justice ) In the context of the facts of the case before the Court, it would not be in the interest of either the Employer or the Employee if the Court were to order reinstatement with full backwages. The Employee was now 51 years old, had been out of employment for seven years and had lost touch with his work. It was doubtful if he could fit in the society where he used to work and where he was not wanted. Under the circumstances, sending him back to the Employer would cause him more mental distress and suffering. The appropriate remedy was to grant him compensation for loss of employment. A total sum of RM489,800 was to be paid by the Employer to the Employee (see p 185D—E, I). Cases referred to: AG of Hong Kong v Ng Yuen Shiu

(Per Edgar Joseph Jr FCJ ) A decision susceptible to Judicial Review is not only open to challenge on the ground of procedural impropriety but also on the grounds of illegality and irrationality; and in practice, this permits the Court to scrutinize such decisions not only for process but also for substance (see p 187B).

( Edgar Joseph Jr FCJ ) The intensity of the Court's review of administrative action may vary according to the nature of the case. The courts in the UK have identified particular classes of cases where the exercise of power will be subject to rigorous examination, eg in cases of interference with human rights or when the result of an impugned decision may put life or liberty at risk. And 'life' in
art 5(1) of the Federal Constitution, as pointed out in Tan Tek Seng v Suruhanjaya Perkhidmatan Pendidikan & Anor
[1996] 1 MLJ 261
, is wide enough to encompass the right to be engaged in lawful and gainful employment (see p 190D, H).

(Per Edgar Joseph Jr FCJ ) In reviewing the Award of the Industrial Court for substance and not just process, the Court was amply supported by the reasoning and the authorities cited and therefore, there was a legal basis for the Court to have done so (see p 190I).

(Per Edgar Joseph Jr FCJ ) Having reviewed the Award of the Industrial Court for substance, members of this Court who comprised the majority were satisfied that upon the uncontradicted affidavit evidence of the Employee, he had been dismissed from service without just cause or excuse. Furthermore, they were satisfied that the Award of the Industrial Court was flawed on grounds of Wednesbury unreasonableness (see p 186E—G).

(Per Edgar Joseph Jr FCJ ) On the question whether the extent of the Court's powers in review jurisdiction includes the power to make consequential orders for fair compensation in favour of the Employee, instead of remitting the case to the Industrial Court to make the same according to law, the members of this Court who comprised the majority were of the view that the entire material evidence for the purpose of assessing the monetary compensation payable being before them, all that was required was a simple arithmetical calculation, a task which this Court should perform (see pp 190I and 191A).

(Per Edgar Joseph Jr FCJ ) It is clear law that appellate review jurisdiction is solely a creature of statute while supervisory review jurisdiction is the creature of the common law and is available in the exercise of the courts' inherent power and its extent may be determined not merely by judicial development but also by legislative intervention (see p 191C—D); R v Cashiobury Hundred Justices
(1823) 3 Dow & Ry 35 followed.

(Per Edgar Joseph Jr FCJ ) It is pertinent to note that the jurisdiction of the courts in Malaysia to issue prerogative orders is derived from the prerogative jurisdiction inherited from English decisions as well as from statute, ie s 25 of the CJA read with para 1 of the Schedule thereto – which is generally in pari materia with art 226(1) of the Indian Constitution – and so it would be wrong to assume that the powers of our courts in the field of Public Law remedies is limited in the same manner as that of the courts in the UK where there are no such equivalent provisions (see pp 195D, G—H and 197B).

(Per Edgar Joseph Jr FCJ ) If, as appeared to be the case, this wider power in the field of Public Law remedies is enjoyed by our courts (and the majority so held), the decision whether to exercise it, and if so, in what manner, are matters which call for the utmost care and circumspection, strict regard being had to the subject matter, the nature of the impugned decision and other relevant discretionary factors. A flexible test whose content will be governed by all the circumstances of the case will have to be applied (see p 197D).

(Per Edgar Joseph Jr FCJ ) The Court is here concerned with an appeal which arose from Judicial Review proceedings whose target was an award of the Industrial Court, an inferior court, and not an administrative decision by bodies or persons who were charged with the performance of public acts or duties. It could not be said, therefore, that by intervening in the manner which the Court proposed to do, the Court would be trespassing into the domain of the executive, thus violating the doctrine of the separation of powers, and so acting undemocratically (see p 198E).

(Per Edgar Joseph Jr FCJ ) In the very special circumstances of this case, to remit the case to the Industrial Court to assess the monetary compensation payable by the Employer to the Employee would seem to be a certain detachment from reality and more importantly, it would not answer the needs of justice. The Court must, therefore, do what the Industrial Court should have done (see p 198F). Cases referred to: Allinson v General Medical Council

(Per Wan Yahya FCJ , dissenting on the issue of consequential relief for wrongful dismissal) The Industrial Court misdirected itself by unduly restricting its attention on the formality rather than the substance of the Employee's case. Although there were ample allegations on biasness, victimization and previous attempts to terminate the Employee's service through charges of misconduct, the Industrial Court appeared to have shut its eyes on these allegations on the premise that the Employer's case was based on redundancy and that the Employee had failed to specify his allegations in more precise form in the statement of the case (see pp�198I and 199A—B).

(Per Wan Yahya FCJ ) The failure of the Industrial Court to consider the issue raised by the Employee amounted to a serious error of fact and law which affected the jurisdiction of that court (see p 199H); Anisminic Ltd v Foreign Compensation Commission
[1969] 2 AC 147
followed.

(Per Wan Yahya FCJ ) The reasoning that the Employee's case could succeed on the basis of an analogy between the power conferred by Indian Constitution and s 25(2) of the CJA was never raised as an argument in this court or in the court below. Where a new or additional question of law is to be considered by any appellate court after the conclusion of the arguments, it must explore by adversarial means not only as to the merit of the new or additional question but also the propriety of entering into it at all. The injustice arising from adjudicating on an argument not raised by a party (in this case, both parties) is not confined to procedural unfairness alone but is tantamount to a denial of the parties' right to be heard on a critical and indeed the decisive issue. Therefore, the argument on art 226 of the Indian Constitution should not be considered as forming part of the Employer's case at all. In the absence of this argument, the Employee could only rely on his subsidiary ground on the inherent powers of the court (see pp 204F—G and 206B—D); Hoe Cheong Products Co Ltd v Cargill Hong Kong Ltd
[1995] 1 WLR 404
followed.

(Per Wan Yahya FCJ ) It had to be borne in mind that the court's supervisory jurisdiction allows it the power to quash and not to act in an appellate capacity to reverse the decision of the Industrial Court. In a certiorari hearing under
O 53 of the RHC, this court did not sit as an appellate court to review and alter the findings of the Industrial Court. Its function was purely supervisory in nature and as such, it possessed neither the original nor appellate jurisdiction to interfere with or substitute the findings of that court with its own determination of facts (see pp�200H—I and 201A—B).

(Per Wan Yahya FCJ ) Having regard to the contrasting nature of jurisdiction envisaged under art 226 of the Constitution of India and s 25(2) of the CJA, the cautious attitude of the Indian courts in exercising the wider jurisdiction, the conflicting authorities with regard to the article itself and the various factor that have been discussed, it would seem judicially inappropriate and unsound for this court to grant consequential remedy to the Employee beyond those contemplated by both the written law and judicial precedents (see p 212D—E).

(Per Wan Yahya FCJ ) An Award of relief could have been obtained in the High Court by Reference under s 33A(5) of the Act had the workman been mindful to do so but he had instead opted to proceed under
O 52 of the RHC and as such it was only fair that he should abide by the remedy available under his certiorari application (see p 203I).

(Per Wan Yahya FCJ ) The discretion as to whether to award compensation in lieu of reinstatement was an issue to be decided by the Industrial Court. In the present case, the Federal Court would be performing its original and appellate but not its supervisory jurisdiction if it were to proceed to determine the issues on the Employee's compensation in lieu of reinstatement (see pp 211G and 212C—D).

(Per Wan Yahya FCJ )
Section 25 of the CJA, being a mere creature of statute and not part of the Federal Constitution, is subject to qualification and modification by other legislation. Section 25(2) must be read with
O 53 of the RHC; and when so read, the powers under the Act do not seem to be unlimited. The power of review under certiorari must be exercised in conformity with the provision of O 53; and when so applied, the power to issue certiorari is confined only to the quashing of the order or remitting it to the inferior court or tribunal for retrial. The court cannot embark on the exercise for determination of consequential remedies, neither can the Indian authorities based on the wider and positive provisions of their constitution be relied on to extend the jurisdiction of the courts beyond what was contemplated by the legislature (see pp�212F and 213A—C).

(Per Wan Yahya FCJ ) The inherent powers of the court as provided under
O 92 r 4 of the RHC must not only be exercised subject to other express provisions of the Rules but it must also not be in conflict with the intention of the legislature to be found within the rules or other substantive legislation (see p 217H); Permodalan MBf Sdn Bhd v Tan Sri Datuk Sri Hamzah bin Abu Samah & Ors
[1988] 1 MLJ 178
; Nainsingh v Koonwarjee
AIR 1970 SC 997
; Padam Sen v State of UP
AIR 1961 SC 218
followed.

(Per Wan Yahya FCJ ) The deliberate intention of the legislature to exclude the High Court's powers to assess and award consequential relief either as damages or compensation is evident from the Rules Committee's preferred election to adopt the narrower provisions of the pre-amended 1977 English Rules of the Supreme Court to those of the much wider post-amended Rules (see p 217I).

(Per Wan Yahya FCJ ) The Employee must have been aware of the two courses of action open to him, ie to resort to the remedy by reference to the High Court under s 33A of the Act or to quash the Industrial Court's order under certiorari. He chose the latter and so should be satisfied with the resulting remedy obtainable from his own choice (see p 218D).

(Per Wan Yahya FCJ ) Inherent powers as contained in O 92 r 4 are indispensible implements for use of the courts to prevent injustice or any abuse of the process of the Court. But the powers themselves stand to be abused if they were to be exercised without circumspection by the courts. The Court would undoubtedly use them in cases where Parliament had omitted to provide in the Act something so glaring which obviously ought to have been there. But on no account should these powers be used to defeat the intention of the legislature, especially so when it had deliberately excluded the use of such particular remedy from any legislation (see p 219G—H); Duport Steels Ltd & Ors v Sirs & Ors
[1980] 1 WLR 142
followed.

(Per Wan Yahya FCJ ) The Court had no jurisdiction to proceed to hear and award compensation after the Industrial Court's order had been quashed. The matter was to be remitted for retrial before the Industrial Court (see p 219I). Cases referred to: Anismic Ltd v Foreign Compensation Commission

(1878) 4 App Cas 30 (refd)
Additional judgment by Edgar Joseph Jr FCJ in reply to Wan Yahya FCJ 's dissenting judgment:

(Per Edgar Joseph Jr FCJ ) The purpose of the proviso to s 25(2) of the CJA is intended simply to make clear the meaning of what has gone before in the enacting clause. It was obvious that the provisions of the proviso to s 25(2) do not affect the powers of the court referred to in para 1 of the Schedule to the CJA; they merely control their exercise by stipulating that they shall be exercised in accordance with any written law or rules of court relating to the same. These requirements would be silently implied in s 25(2) even without the proviso (see pp 221I and 222A).

(Per Edgar Joseph Jr FCJ ) The words 'in accordance with any written law' appearing in the proviso to s 25(2), are the equivalent of 'not repugnant tO' or 'not inconsistent with statute law'. It follows that recourse may be had to para 1 of the Schedule to derive jurisdiction to grant the reliefs specified therein unless there is explicit statutory prohibition. So far as the majority of the members of this Court were aware, there is no written law which prohibited this Court from making the orders they had made in this case (see p 222B).

(Per Edgar Joseph Jr FCJ ) While
O 53 of the RHC can only prescribe the procedure and practice to be followed by parties when applying for Judicial Review, the source of power enjoyed by our courts to grant relief in Judicial Review proceedings is the prerogative jurisdiction inherited from the UK courts and most importantly, para 1 of the Schedule read with s 25 of the CJA. The proviso to s 25(2), and more particularly, the RHC, do not – and indeed cannot – narrow down or diminish or curtail the scope of the powers conferred upon our courts in Judicial Review proceedings (see p 223I).

(Per Edgar Joseph Jr FCJ ) As for the criticism that it was not open to this Court to find that the Employee had been dismissed from service without just cause or excuse, because this was a question of fact for the Industrial Court, by virtue of the Act, although the basis of this criticism appeared to be the principle enunciated by Lord Brightman in R v Hillingdon LBC, ex p Puhlhofer
[1986] AC 484
, there were two exceptions thereto which tended to blur the conceptual distinction between errors of law and fact. The two exceptions relevant to the present case are: (a) reliance upon an erroneous factual conclusion may itself offend against the principles of illegality or rationality; and (b) where there is no evidence to support a conclusion, there is necessarily an error of law in the decision arrived at. The Court's conclusion that the Employee had been dismissed from service without just cause or excuse was arrived at as a result of reviewing the Award not only for process but also for substance and came within the range of these two exceptions (see p 224B, D—G, I); Council of Civil Service Unions & Ors v Minister for the Civil Service
[1985] AC 374
; R v Hillingdon LBC, ex p Puhlhofer
[1986] AC 484
; Edwards v Bairstow
[1956] AC 14
; R v Hillingdon LBC, ex p Islam (Tafazzul)
[1983] 1 AC 688
followed.

(Per Edgar Joseph Jr FCJ ) In considering the words 'for the enforcement of the rights conferred by Part II of the Constitution or any of them, or for any purpose' appearing in para 1 of the Schedule, the word 'enforcement' was significant from the point of view of whether this court had jurisdiction to find that the Employee had been dismissed from service without just cause or excuse and to make the consequential order for the payment of compensation. 'Enforcement' meant 'compelling observance of' and in deciding in favour of the Employee on these matters, this Court was compelling observance of the right to livelihood which is one of the fundamental rights under Pt II of the Constitution (see p 225D—G); R v Bates
[1982] 2 NSWLR 894
followed.

(Per Edgar Joseph Jr FCJ ) In appropriate circumstances, such as obtained here, our High Courts have the power not merely to quash an Award of the Industrial Court but to go on to make a finding that an employee has been dismissed from service without just cause or excuse, and when necessary, to award fair compensation (see p 227H); Hong Leong Equipment Sdn Bhd v Liew Fook Chuan
[1996] 1 MLJ 481
followed.

(Per Edgar Joseph Jr FCJ ) The powers exercisable by this court when hearing this appeal would, by reason of
s 30 of the Interpretation Acts 1948 and 1967, be the powers provided for by sub-s (4) of s 69 of the CJA (in the form that it took prior to its amendment on 24 June 1994 by the Courts of Judicature (Amendment) Act 1994
s 16(b) when the words 'Court of Appeal' was substituted for the words 'Supreme Court'), which gives this court power not only to make any order which ought to have been made but also to 'make such further or other orders as the case requires'. These powers are sufficient to enable the court to find that the Employee had been dismissed from service without just cause or excuse and to make the consequential orders for fair compensation (see p 228C—E); Sungei Biak Tin Mines Ltd v Saw Choo Theng & Anor
[1970] 2 MLJ 226
followed.

(Per Edgar Joseph Jr FCJ ) With regard to the question whether the Employee had been dismissed from service for just cause or excuse, the allegations by the Employee made on affidavit that the purported termination of his services by letter although ostensibly in pursuance of a retrenchment exercise was really a device to cloak a mala fide exercise of power – and thus the decision of the Industrial Court that he had been dismissed from service for just cause or excuse was 'patently erroneous and manifestly perverse' – had not been contradicted by the Employer by counter-affidavit, with the result that the allegations should have been deemed admitted. In such a situation, involving as it does a man's livelihood, the Employee should not be exposed to the hazard, anxiety and delay of proceedings before a freshly constituted tribunal and thus, to the risk of misapplication of the law (see pp 229E—F and 231B).

(Per Edgar Joseph Jr FCJ ) In any event, at the end of the argument regarding this part of the case, the members of this Court who comprised the majority were satisfied, upon the whole of the evidence appearing in the Record of Appeal, that the Award of the Industrial Court was flawed on the grounds of Wednesbury unreasonableness and that the Employee had been dismissed from service without just cause or excuse (see p 231C).

(Per Edgar Joseph Jr FCJ ) With regard to the criticism that it was inappropriate for this Court to have made the consequential orders concerned as the question whether the Employee should be reinstated or paid compensation was a question of fact for the determination of the Industrial Court and not this Court, the criticism overlooked the point that before this Court, counsel for the Employee had confined his contention to compensation. Therefore, no other order except that of compensation would have been appropriate and so reinstatement ceased to be an issue (see p 232A).

(Per Edgar Joseph Jr FCJ ) In considering the question whether consequential reliefs ought to be granted, the point was reiterated that all the material evidence for the purpose of assessing the monetary compensation payable was before the Court, and there being no suggestion to the contrary by counsel for the Employer, all that was required was a simple arithmetical calculation in order to avoid unnecessary prolongation of proceedings (see p 231F—G).

(Per Edgar Joseph Jr FCJ ) It was difficult to see how the Employee could be criticized for having elected to proceed by way of Judicial Review under O 53 instead of a Reference on a question of law under s 33A of the Act. Unlike a Reference under s 33A, Judicial Review is a discretionary jurisdiction. None of the discretionary bars applies to Reference proceedings under s 33A (see pp 235H and 236A, E).

(Per Edgar Joseph Jr FCJ ) With regard to the criticism as to reliance on the inherent powers of the High Court, it was agreed that the Court was not at liberty to resort to its inherent powers in violation of a statutory provision. However, the Court could not agree with the suggestion that their use should be confined to situations where Parliament had omitted to provide in the Act (concerned) something so glaring which ought obviously to have been there. The nature, extent, juridical basis and relation between the inherent jurisdiction and the rules of court have been correctly stated by Sir Jack Jacob QC, Senior Master of the Supreme Court in his article, 'The Inherent Jurisdiction of the Court' [1970] Current Legal Problems 23 (see p 237B—C).

(Per Edgar Joseph Jr FCJ ) Order 92 r 4 is a unique rule of court, for while it neither defines nor gives jurisdiction, yet it serves as a reminder and confirmation of the common law powers of the court, which are residuary or reserve powers and a separate and distinct source of jurisdiction from the powers of the court. In other words, even without O 92 r 4, the inherent powers of the High Court would still be there (see pp 238I and 239A—B). Cases referred to: Arulpragasan a/l Sandaraju v PP

p.text: Perayu ('Pekerja tersebut') telah dipecat oleh penentang kedua, Persatuan Koperasi Pengguna Malaysia Bhd ('Majikan tersebut') selepas dua tahun bekerja. Pekerja tersebut membuat representasi kepada Ketua Pengarah Perhubungan Perindustrian di bawah s 20(1) Akta Perhubungan Perindustrian 1967 ('Akta tersebut') dengan mendakwa bahawa beliau telah dipecat oleh Majikan tersebut tanpa sebab atau alasan yang munasabah dan meminta supaya beliau dikembalikan jawatannya, dan kegagalan berbuat demikian akan memberikannya hak kepada pampasan munasabah atas kehilangan pendapatan dan kehilangan sebahagian besar ganjaran, kadar Kumpulan Wang Simpanan Pekerja yang lebih tinggi, pelucutan pinjaman perumahan dan kemudahan lain. Representasinya telah dirujuk kepada Mahkamah Perusahaan, yang kemudiannya memutuskan bahawa Pekerja tersebut telah dipecat dengan sebab atau alasan yang munasabah. Pekerja tersebut memohon kepada Mahkamah Tinggi untuk Kajian Semula Kehakiman atas beberapa alasan yang dinyatakan dalam afidavit menyokong, yang dibangkitkan dalam penghakiman Mahkamah Persekutuan tetapi permohonan beliau telah ditolak. Pekerja tersebut kemudiannya merayu kepada Mahkamah Persekutuan terhadap keputusan Mahkamah Tinggi. Pada umumnya, persoalan undang-undang untuk penentuan Mahkamah Persekutuan adalah: (i) sama ada Award Mahkamah Perusahaan harus dibatalkan; dan (ii) jika demikian, sama ada dalam keadaan khusus kes ini Mahkamah Persekutuan berkuasa untuk bukan sahaja membatalkan Award Mahkamah Perusahaan dan meremitkan kes kepada Mahkamah Perusahaan untuk mendengar dan menentukan persoalan tersebut menurut undang-undang tetapi untuk mengambil langkah selanjutnya dan membuat pendapat bahawa Pekerja tersebut telah dipecat tanpa sebab atau alasan yang munasabah, dan untuk mengawardkan pampasan yang adil.
Diputuskan , membenarkan rayuan Pekerja tersebut:

(Oleh Eusoff Chin Ketua Hakim ) Terdapat bukti prima facie bahawa sebab-sebab yang diberikan atas pemberhentian perkhidmatan Pekerja tersebut dalam surat Majikan tersebut yang bertarikh 20 April 1988 adalah tidak ikhlas dan bahawa pemberhentian yang dikatakan adalah mala fide. Mahkamah Perusahaan dalam Awardnya langsung tidak menumpukan perhatian kepada isu prasangka yang dibangkitkan oleh Pekerja tersebut yang merupakan tunggak utama kesnya dalam pandangan Mahkamah ini. Kegagalan Mahkamah Perusahaan untuk menumpukan perhatian kepada isu asas ini merupakan suatu kesilapan serius yang menjejaskan bidang kuasa dan telah mengakibat dalam pembatalan Award tersebut (lihat ms 177F, H).

(Oleh Eusoff Chin Ketua Hakim ) Adalah undang-undang mantap bahawa sesuatu pihak adalah terikat oleh plidingnya. Mahkamah Perusahaan haruslah meneliti pliding dan mengenal pasti isu-isu, mengambil keterangan, mendengar hujah pihak-pihak dan mengisytihar penghakimannya dengan mengambil kira isu-isu. Mahkamah Perusahaan tidak boleh mengabaikan pliding dan menganggapnya sebagai sifat menunjuk-nunjuk pandai atau formalisme semata-mata, sebab jika ia berbuat demikian, ia mungkin terlepas isu-isu, menerima keterangan yang tidak relevan kepada isu-isu atau menolak keterangan yang relevan kepada isu-isu dan membuat kesimpulan yang salah. Dalam kes ini, Mahkamah Perusahaan telah gagal sama sekali untuk mengambil kira pengataan salah laku tetapi membuat kesimpulan bahawa oleh kerana surat pemberhentian adalah berasaskan pelaksanaan penghematan, ia tidak terikat dan oleh itu tidak wajib mempertimbangkan isu-isu prasangka dan salah laku (lihat ms 178B—D).

(Oleh Eusoff Chin Ketua Hakim ) Tiada peruntukan dalam
Akta Mahkamah Kehakiman 1964 ('AMK'), Kaedah-Kaedah Mahkamah Tinggi 1980 ('KMT') atau Akta tersebut sama ada secara nyata atau tersirat yang melarang Mahkamah Tinggi daripada memberikan apa-apa relief sebagaimana yang diperuntukkan dalam Akta tersebut ketika membatalkan Award Mahkamah Perusahaan. Mahkamah tidak boleh menolak suatu peruntukan nyata undang-undang, tetapi jika tiadanya peruntukan nyata dalam statut, maka Mahkamah boleh melaksanakan kuasanya dalam kes yang wajar (lihat ms 181I); Zainal Abidin v Century Hotel
[1982] 1 MLJ 260
diikut.

(Oleh Eusoff Chin Ketua Hakim ) Seksyen 33B Akta tersebut memperuntukkan bahawa suatu Award Mahkamah Perusahaan adalah terakhir dan muktamad dan tidak boleh dicabar, dirayu, dikaji semula, diketepikan atau dipersoalkan di mana-mana mahkamah undang-undang. Namun begitu, Mahkamah Tinggi dan Mahkamah Persekutuan kita telah campur tangan dengan membatalkan Award Mahkamah Perusahaan dalam kes yang wajar, demi mencapai keadilan. Oleh yang demikian, jika pun statut mengisytihar sesuatu Award adalah terakhir, Mahkamah masih boleh campur tangan (lihat ms 182I); Sungai Wangi Estate v Uni
[1975] 1 MLJ 136
; Minister of Labour, Malaysia v National Union of Journalists, Malaysia
[1991] 1 MLJ 24
diikut.

(Oleh Eusoff Chin Ketua Hakim ) Adalah jelas bahawa Mahkamah Tinggi dan Mahkamah Persekutuan telah menerima-pakai suatu pendekatan yang liberal dan progresif dalam prosiding certiorari. Di mana fakta tertentu kes menghendakinya, Mahkamah Tinggi harus berusaha memulihkan ketidakadilan apabila ia dibawa ke pengetahuan Mahkamah berbanding dengan menafikan relief kepada pihak terkilan atas alasan yang teknikal dan sempit semata-mata. Mahkamah Tinggi harus membentuk relief menurut tuntutan keadilan (lihat ms 183C); Sungai Wangi Estate v Uni
[1975] 1 MLJ 136
; Minister of Labour, Malaysia v National Union of Journalists, Malaysia
[1991] 1 MLJ 24
diikut.

(Oleh Eusoff Chin Ketua Hakim ) Seksyen 30(3) Akta tersebut menghendaki Mahkamah Perusahaan membuat Awardnya tanpa kelewatan dan di mana ia boleh dilaksanakan dalam tempoh masa 30 hari. Di sini, Pekerja tersebut telah menganggur selama tujuh tahun, dan objek dan semangat Akta tersebut agar pertikaian perindustrian diselesaikan dengan cepat demi kepentingan negara telah ditewaskan dan dikecewakan. Oleh yang demikian, mahkamah tidak wajib untuk terus mencapai keputusan yang tidak adil kepada rakyat dan memudaratkan kesejahteraan masyarakat umum semata-mata akibat sesuatu yang diputuskan beberapa kurun dahulu (lihat ms 184D, F).

(Oleh Eusoff Chin Ketua Hakim ) Berdasarkan fakta atas rekod, ini merupakan suatu kes yang wajar di mana bidang kuasa Mahkamah tidak harus berakhir dengan pembatalan Award. Bidang kuasa Mahkamah Tinggi tidak patut dihadkan atau dikurangkan menerusi rujukan sahaja kepada perkembangan bersejarah lama dalam mana writ certiorari telah dikembangkan dan diberikan oleh mahkamah di England. Jika permohonan untuk certiorari ditolak, ini bermakna perkara itu berakhir. Tetapi jika permohonan dibenarkan, Mahkamah harus membentuk perintah itu. Jika ia hanya membenarkan certiorari bagi membatalkan Award dan tidak lebih daripada itu, ini akan melucut writ daripada maknanya yang penting dan efektif dan boleh mengakibat dalam ketidakadilan serius kepada Pekerja tersebut (lihat ms 184F—H).

(Oleh Eusoff Chin Ketua Hakim ) Setakat mana yang boleh, kekhuatiran dan usaha Mahkamah haruslah ditumpukan terhadap pemulihan ketidakadilan apabila ia dibawa ke pengetahuan Mahkamah. Atas fakta kes di hadapan Mahkamah, jika perkara ini diremit kepada Mahkamah Perusahaan ini bermakna pertikaian akan dilanjutkan, dan ini tidaklah adil kepada ataupun sesuai dengan kepentingan pihak-pihak. Dalam keadaan ini, keadilan menuntut bahawa supaya kelewatan dan perbelanjaan lanjut dielakkan, Mahkamah haruslah menentukan relief berbangkit berbanding dengan jika kes diremit kepada Mahkamah Perusahaan untuk tujuan tersebut (lihat ms 184I dan 185A).

(Oleh Eusoff Chin Ketua Hakim ) Dalam konteks fakta kes di hadapan Mahkamah, bukanlah dalam kepentingan Majikan tersebut ataupun Pekerja tersebut jika Mahkamah memerintahkan pengembalian kedudukan jawatan dengan bayaran gaji kebelakangan penuh. Pekerja tersebut kini berusia 51 tahun, telah menganggur selama tujuh tahun dan sudah tidak biasa dengan pekerjaannya. Adalah diragui jika beliau dapat menyesuaikan diri dalam masyarakat di mana dia bekerja dahulu dan di mana dia tidak dikehendaki. Di bawah keadaan demikian, menghantarnya semula kepada Majikan tersebut akan menyebabkan distres dan penderitaan mental. Remedi yang wajar adalah untuk memberikannya pampasan atas kehilangan pekerjaan. Jumlah sebanyak RM489,800 harus dibayar oleh Majikan tersebut kepada Pekerja tersebut (lihat ms 185D—E, I).

(Oleh Edgar Joseph Jr HMP ) Suatu keputusan yang tertakluk kepada Kajian Semula Kehakiman bukan sahaja terbuka kepada cabaran atas alasan kesalahan prosedur malah juga atas alasan kepenyalahan undang-undang dan ketidakrasionalan; dan dalam amalan, ini membenarkan Mahkamah meneliti keputusan sedemikian bukan sahaja untuk proses tetapi juga untuk kekukuhan (lihat ms 187B).

(Oleh Edgar Joseph Jr HMP ) Kekerapan Kajian Semula tindakan pentadbiran oleh Mahkamah boleh ubah menurut sifat kes. Mahkamah di UK telah mengenal pasti kelas kes tertentu di mana pelaksanaan kuasa adalah tertakluk kepada pemeriksaan ketat, misalnya dalam kes campur tangan hak manusia atau apabila kesan suatu keputusan yang dipersoalkan boleh menjejaskan kehidupan atau kebebasan. Dan 'kehidupan' dalam perkara 5(1) Perlembagaan Persekutuan, seperti yang ditegaskan dalam Tan Tek Seng v Suruhanjaya Pendidikan & Anor
[1996] 1 MLJ 261
, adalah cukup luas bagi meliputi hak kepada pekerjaan yang sah dan menguntungkan (lihat ms 190D, H).

(Oleh Edgar Joseph Jr HMP ) Dalam mengkaji semula Award Mahkamah Perusahaan atas kekukuhan dan bukan proses sahaja, Mahkamah disokong sepenuhnya oleh taakulan dan autoriti yang disebut dan oleh itu, terdapatnya dasar yang sah untuk Mahkamah berbuat demikian (lihat ms 190I).

(Oleh Edgar Joseph Jr HMP ) Setelah mengkaji semula Award Mahkamah Perusahaan untuk kekukuhan, ahli Mahkamah ini yang membentuk majoriti berpuas hati bahawa atas keterangan afidavit Pekerja tersebut yang tidak dicabar, beliau telah dipecat tanpa sebab atau alasan yang munasabah. Tambahan pula, mereka berpuas hati bahawa Award Mahkamah Perusahaan adalah cacat atas alasan ketidakmunasabahan Wednesbury (lihat ms 186E—G).

(Oleh Edgar Joseph Jr HMP ) Berhubung dengan soalan sama ada takat kuasa Mahkamah dalam bidang kuasa kajian semula termasuk kuasa untuk membuat perintah berbangkit bagi pampasan munasabah memihak kepada Pekerja tersebut, ahli Mahkamah ini yang membentuk majoriti berpandangan bahawa oleh kerana bukti material pada keseluruhannya untuk tujuan taksiran pampasan wang yang harus dibayar boleh didapati di hadapan mereka, apa yang perlu adalah pengiraan aritmetik yang mudah, suatu tugas yang harus dilaksanakan oleh Mahkamah ini (lihat ms 190I dan 191A).

(Oleh Edgar Joseph Jr HMP ) Adalah undang-undang mantap bahawa bidang kuasa kajian semula rayuan hanyalah suatu rekaan statut sementara bidang kuasa kajian semula penyeliaan adalah rekaan common law dan boleh didapati dalam pelaksanaan kuasa sedia ada mahkamah dan takatnya boleh ditentukan bukan hanya melalui perkembangan kehakiman tetapi juga menerusi campur tangan perundangan (lihat ms 191C—D); R v Cashiobury Hundred Justices
(1823) 3 Dow & Ry 35 diikut.

(Oleh Edgar Joseph Jr HMP ) Adalah penting untuk mengingati bahawa bidang kuasa mahkamah di Malaysia untuk mengeluarkan perintah prerogatif diperolehi daripada bidang kuasa prerogatif yang diwarisi daripada keputusan Inggeris dan juga daripada statut, iaitu s 25 AMK dibaca dengan perenggan�1 Jadual – yang pada umumnya adalah pari materia dengan perkara 226(1) Perlembagaan India – dan oleh itu adalah salah untuk menganggap bahawa kuasa mahkamah kita dalam bidang remedi Undang-Undang Awam adalah terhad dalam cara yang sama dengan mahkamah di UK di mana tiadanya peruntukan setara sedemikian (lihat ms 195D, G—H dan 197B).

(Oleh Edgar Joseph Jr HMP ) Jika kuasa yang lebih luas dalam bidang remedi Undang-Undang Awam dinikmati oleh mahkamah kita (dan diputuskan demikian oleh majoriti), keputusan sama ada untuk melaksanakannya, dan jika demikian, dalam apa cara, adalah perkara yang menghendaki ketelitian yang tinggi dan berhati-hati, dengan mengambil kira perkara subjek, sifat keputusan yang dipersoalkan dan faktor budi bicara relevan yang lain. Suatu ujian fleksibel yang mana kandungannya dikuasai oleh kesemua keadaan kes harus dipakai (lihat ms 197D).

(Oleh Edgar Joseph Jr HMP ) Di sini Mahkamah mementingkan rayuan yang timbul daripada prosiding Kajian Semula Kehakiman yang sasarannya adalah Award Mahkamah Perusahaan, sebuah mahkamah rendah, dan bukan keputusan pentadbiran oleh perbadanan atau orang yang ditugaskan dengan pelaksanaan tindakan awam. Oleh yang demikian, tidak boleh dikatakan bahawa dengan mencampur tangan dalam cara sebagaimana yang dicadangkan oleh Mahkamah, Mahkamah akan mencerobohi domain eksekutif, justeru itu melanggar doktrin perasingan kuasa, dan bertindak secara tidak demokratik (lihat ms 198E).

(Oleh Edgar Joseph Jr HMP ) Dalam keadaan khas kes ini, peremitan kes kepada Mahkamah Perusahaan bagi menaksir pampasan wang yang harus dibayar daripada Majikan tersebut kepada Pekerja tersebut seolah-olah merupakan suatu pemisahan daripada realiti dan lebih utamanya, ia tidak akan menjawab keperluan keadilan. Oleh itu, Mahkamah mestilah membuat apa yang sepatutnya telah dilakukan oleh Mahkamah Perusahaan (lihat ms 198F).

(Oleh Wan Yahya HMP , bertentangan atas isu relief berbangkit untuk pemecatan salah) Mahkamah Perusahaan telah menyalah arah diri dengan menghadkan perhatian secara terlampau kepada formaliti dan bukan kekukuhan kes Pekerja tersebut. Walaupun terdapat banyak pengataan atas prasangka, pemangsaan dan beberapa percubaan untuk memberhentikan perkhidmatan Pekerja tersebut melalui pertuduhan salah laku, nampaknya Mahkamah Perusahaan telah mengabaikan pengataan ini atas premis bahawa kes Majikan tersebut adalah berasaskan lebihan dan bahawa Pekerja tersebut telah gagal menetapkan pengataannya dalam bentuk yang lebih tepat dalam pernyataan kes (lihat ms�198I dan 199A—B).

(Oleh Wan Yahya HMP ) Kegagalan Mahkamah Perusahaan untuk mempertimbangkan isu yang dibangkitkan oleh Pekerja tersebut sama seperti suatu kesilapan fakta dan undang-undang yang serius yang menjejaskan bidang kuasa mahkamah itu (lihat ms 199H); Anisminic Ltd v Foreign Compensation Commission
[1969] 2 AC 147
diikut.

(Oleh Wan Yahya HMP ) Taakulan bahawa kes Pekerja tersebut boleh berjaya atas dasar suatu analogi antara kuasa yang dikurniakan oleh Perlembagaan India dan s 25(2) AMK tidak pernah dibangkitkan sebagai suatu hujah di mahkamah ini atau di mahkamah bawah. Di mana persoalan undang-undang yang baru atau sebagai tambahan harus dipertimbangkan oleh mana-mana mahkamah rayuan selepas tamatnya hujah-hujah, ia mestilah memeriksa dengan teliti melalui cara adversarial bukan sahaja merit persoalan baru atau tambahan tetapi juga kebijaksanaan berbuat demikian. Ketidakadilan yang timbul daripada memutus suatu hujah yang tidak dibangkitkan oleh sesuatu pihak (dalam kes ini, kedua-dua pihak) tidak terhad kepada ketidakadilan prosedur sahaja tetapi terjumlah kepada penafian hak pihak-pihak untuk didengar atas isu yang kritikal dan muktamad. Oleh yang demikian, hujah atas perkara 226 Perlembagaan India tidak harus diambil kira sebagai membentuk sebahagian daripada kes penentang sama sekali. Dalam ketiadaan hujah ini, Pekerja tersebut hanya boleh bergantung kepada alasan subsidiarinya atas kuasa sedia ada mahkamah (lihat ms 204F—G dan 206B—D); Hoe Cheong Products Co Ltd v Cargill Hong Kong Ltd
[1995] 1 WLR 404
diikut

(Oleh Wan Yahya HMP ) Harus diingati bahawa bidang kuasa penyeliaan mahkamah memberikannya kuasa untuk membatal dan bukan untuk bertindak dalam keupayaan rayuan bagi mengakas keputusan Mahkamah Perusahaan. Dalam pembicaraan certiorari di bawah A 53 KMT, mahkamah ini tidak bersidang sebagai mahkamah rayuan bagi mengkaji semula pendapat Mahkamah Perusahaan. Fungsinya bersifat penyeliaan sahaja dan dengan itu, ia tidak mempunyai bidang kuasa asal atau rayuan untuk mencampur tangan atau mengganti pendapat mahkamah itu dengan penentuan fakta sendiri (lihat ms�200H—I dan 201A—B).

(Oleh Wan Yahya HMP ) Dengan mengambil kira ciri bidang kuasa yang bertentangan yang dibayangkan di bawah perkara 226 Perlembagaan India dan s 25(2) AMK, sikap waspada mahkamah India dalam melaksanakan bidang kuasa yang lebih luas, autoriti yang bercanggah berhubung dengan perkara itu sendiri dan pelbagai faktor yang telah dibincangkan, nampaknya ia adalah tidak wajar dan tidak kukuh untuk mahkamah ini memberikan remedi berbangkit kepada Pekerja tersebut melampaui apa yang dihasratkan oleh kedua-dua undang-undang bertulis dan duluan kehakiman (lihat ms 212D—E).

(Oleh Wan Yahya HMP ) Sesuatu Award relief boleh diperolehi di Mahkamah Tinggi melalui Rujukan di bawah s 33A(5) Akta tersebut jika pekerja sedar akan berbuat demikian tetapi sebaliknya beliau telah memilih untuk meneruskan tindakan di bawah A 52 KMT dan oleh yang demikian adalah adil bahawa beliau mematuhi remedi yang didapati di bawah permohonan certiorari (lihat ms�203I).

(Oleh Wan Yahya HMP ) Budi bicara sama ada untuk mengaward pampasan atau tidak sebagai mengganti pengembalian kedudukan jawatan merupakan suatu isu yang harus ditentukan oleh Mahkamah Perusahaan. Dalam kes ini, Mahkamah Perusahaan melaksanakan bidang kuasa asal dan rayuan – tetapi bukan bidang kuasa penyeliaan – jika ia terus menentukan isu-isu atas pampasan pihak menuntut sebagai ganti pengembalian kedudukan jawatan (lihat ms 211G dan 212C—D).

(Oleh Wan Yahya HMP ) Seksyen 25 AMK, yang merupakan suatu rekaan statut dan bukan sebahagian daripada Perlembagaan Persekutuan, adalah tertakluk kepada kelulusan dan pengubahsuaian oleh perundangan lain. Seksyen 25(2) hendaklah dibaca dengan A 53 KMT; dan apabila dibaca bersama, kuasa di bawah Akta tersebut tidak kelihatan tidak terhad. Kuasa kajian semula di bawah certiorari hendaklah dilaksanakan menurut peruntukan A 53 dan apabila dipakai, kuasa untuk mengeluarkan certiorari hanyalah dibataskan kepada pembatalan perintah atau meremitkannya kepada mahkamah atau tribunal bawahan untuk perbicaraan semula. Mahkamah tidak boleh memulakan pelaksanaan untuk penentuan remedi berbangkit, dan tidak boleh juga bergantung kepada autoriti India yang berdasarkan peruntukan perlembagaan yang lebih luas dan positif bagi melanjutkan bidang kuasa mahkamah melampaui apa yang dihasratkan oleh perundangan (lihat ms 212F dan 213A—C).

(Oleh Wan Yahya HMP ) Kuasa sedia ada mahkamah seperti yang diperuntukkan di bawah A 92 k 4 KMT mestilah dilaksanakan bukan sahaja tertakluk kepada peruntukan nyata lain Kaedah tersebut tetapi ia juga haruslah tidak bertentangan dengan hasrat perundangan yang boleh didapati dalam kaedah atau perundangan substantif yang lain (lihat ms 217H).

(Oleh Wan Yahya HMP ) Hasrat perundangan yang disengajakan untuk mengecualikan kuasa Mahkamah Tinggi untuk menaksir dan mengaward relief berbangkit sama ada sebagai ganti rugi ataupun pampasan adalah jelas daripada pilihan Jawatankuasa Kaedah untuk menerimapakai peruntukan pra-pindaan Kaedah-Kaedah Mahkamah Agung Inggeris 1977 yang lebih terbatas dan bukan Kaedah yang dipinda yang lebih meluas (lihat ms�217I).

(Oleh Wan Yahya HMP ) Pekerja tersebut seharusnya sedar akan dua jalan tindakan yang terbuka kepadanya, iaitu bergantung kepada remedi menerusi rujukan kepada Mahkamah Tinggi di bawah s 33A Akta tersebut atau untuk membatalkan perintah Mahkamah Perusahaan di bawah certiorari. Beliau telah memilih jalan kedua dan patut berpuas hati dengan remedi yang timbul daripada pilihan sendiri (lihat ms 218D).

(Oleh Wan Yahya HMP ) Kuasa sedia ada seperti yang termaktub dalam A 92 k 4 adalah alat yang amat diperlukan untuk kegunaan mahkamah bagi mencegah ketidakadilan atau sebarang penyalahgunaan proses mahkamah. Tetapi kuasa-kuasa tersebut boleh disalahguna jika dilaksanakan tanpa diawasi oleh mahkamah. Mahkamah tetap akan menggunakannya dalam kes di mana Parlimen telah tertinggal memperuntukkan dalam Akta apa yang nyata sekali sepatutnya dimasukkan. Akan tetapi kuasa-kuasa ini tidak patut sekali-kali digunakan bagi menewaskan hasrat perundangan, terutamanya apabila ia telah dengan sengajanya mengecualikan penggunaan remedi tertentu daripada apa-apa perundangan (lihat ms 219G—H); Duport Steels Ltd & Ors v Sirs & Ors
[1980] 1 WLR 142
diikut.

(Oleh Wan Yahya HMP ) Mahkamah tidak mempunyai bidang kuasa untuk terus mendengar dan mengawardkan pampasan setelah perintah Mahkamah Perusahaan dibatalkan. Perkara ini haruslah diremitkan untuk perbicaraan semula di hadapan Mahkamah Perusahaan (lihat ms 219I).
Penghakiman tambahan Edgar Joseph Jr HMP sebagai jawapan penghakiman bertentangan Wan Yahya HMP :

(Oleh Edgar Joseph Jr HMP ) Proviso s 25(2) AMK hanyalah bertujuan menjelaskan maksud apa yang telah dimasukkan dalam fasal menggubal. Adalah nyata bahawa peruntukan-peruntukan proviso s 25(2) tidak menjejaskan kuasa mahkamah yang dirujuk dalam perenggan 1 Jadual kepada AMK; mereka hanya mengawal pelaksanaan dengan mensyaratkan bahawa mereka akan dilaksanakan menurut apa-apa undang-undang bertulis atau kaedah mahkamah yang berkaitan. Keperluan ini memang tersirat secara senyap dalam s 25(2) walaupun tanpa proviso (lihat ms 221I dan 222A).

(Oleh Edgar Joseph Jr HMP ) Perkataan 'mengikut mana-mana undang-undang bertulis' yang muncul dalam proviso s 25(2) adalah sama seperti 'tidak bertentangan dengan' atau 'bukan tidak konsisten dengan undang-undang statut'. Ini bermakna bahawa perenggan 1 Jadual boleh digunakan untuk memperolehi bidang kuasa bagi memberikan relief yang disyaratkan dalamnya melainkan terdapatnya larangan statutori yang eksplisit. Sejauh mana majoriti ahli Mahkamah ini sedar, tiadanya undang-undang bertulis yang melarang Mahkamah ini daripada membuat perintah yang telah dibuat dalam kes ini (lihat ms 222B).

(Oleh Edgar Joseph Jr HMP ) Sedangkan A 53 KMT hanya boleh mensyaratkan prosedur dan amalan yang perlu dipatuhi oleh pihak-pihak ketika memohon Kajian Semula Kehakiman, sumber kuasa yang dinikmati oleh mahkamah kita bagi memberikan relief dalam prosiding Kajian Semula Kehakiman adalah bidang kuasa prerogatif yang diwarisi daripada mahkamah UK dan yang terutama, perenggan 1 Jadual dibaca dengan s 25 AMK. Proviso s 25(2), dan khususnya, KMT, tidak – dan memang tidak boleh – membataskan atau mengurangkan atau menghadkan skop kuasa yang dikurniakan ke atas mahkamah kita dalam prosiding Kajian Semula Kehakiman (lihat ms 223I).

(Oleh Edgar Joseph Jr HMP ) Berkaitan dengan kritikan bahawa ianya tidak terbuka kepada Mahkamah ini untuk mendapati bahawa Pekerja tersebut telah dipecat tanpa sebab atau alasan yang munasabah, sebab ia adalah persoalan fakta untuk Mahkamah Perusahaan, menerusi Akta tersebut, walaupun dasar kritikan ini seolah-olah merupakan prinsip yang dinyatakan oleh Lord Brightman dalam R v Hillingdon LBC, ex p Puhlhofer
[1986] AC 484
, terdapat dua kekecualian penting yang boleh mengaburkan perbezaan konsepsi antara kesilapan undang-undang dan fakta. Dua kekecualian yang relevan kepada kes ini adalah: (i) pergantungan pada suatu kesimpulan faktual yang salah boleh melanggar prinsip kepenyalahan undang-undang atau kerasionalan; dan (ii) di mana tiada bukti yang menyokong sesuatu kesimpulan, semestinya terdapat kesilapan undang-undang dalam keputusan yang dicapai. Kesimpulan Mahkamah bahawa Pekerja tersebut telah dipecat tanpa sebab atau alasan yang munasabah tercapai akibat kajian semula Award bukan sahaja untuk proses tetapi juga untuk kekukuhan dan adalah termaktub dalam dua kekecualian tersebut (lihat ms 224B, D—G, I); Council of Civil Service Unions & Ors v Minister for the Civil Service
[1985] AC 374
; R v Hillingdon LB, ex p Puhlhofer
[1986] AC 484
; Edwards v Bairstow
[1956] AC 14
; R v Hillingdon LBC, ex p Islam (Tafazzul)
[1983] 1 AC 688
diikut.

(Oleh Edgar Joseph Jr HMP ) Dalam mempertimbangkan perkataan-perkataan 'bagi menguatkuasakan hak-hak yang diberikan oleh Bahagian II Perlembagaan, atau mana-mana daripadanya, atau bagi apa-apa maksud' yang menonjol dalam perenggan 1 Jadual, perkataan 'menguatkuasakan' adalah penting dari pandangan sama ada mahkamah ini mempunyai bidang kuasa untuk membuat pendapat bahawa Pekerja tersebut telah dipecat tanpa sebab atau alasan yang munasabah dan untuk membuat perintah berbangkit bagi bayaran pampasan. 'Menguatkuasakan' bermakna 'mendorong pematuhan' dan dalam membuat keputusan memihak kepada Pekerja tersebut dalam perkara ini, Mahkamah ini mendorong pematuhan hak kepada mata pencarian yang merupakan satu daripada hak asasi di bawah Bhg II Perlembagaan (lihat ms 225D—G); R v Bates
[1982] 2 NSWLR 894
diikut.

(Oleh Edgar Joseph Jr HMP ) Dalam keadaan yang wajar, sebagaimana yang didapati di sini, Mahkamah Tinggi kita mempunyai kuasa bukan sahaja untuk membatalkan sesuatu Award Mahkamah Perusahaan tetapi untuk terus membuat pendapat bahawa seseorang pekerja telah dipecat tanpa sebab atau alasan yang munasabah, dan jika perlu, untuk mengawardkan pampasan yang adil (lihat ms 227H); Hong Leong Equipment Sdn Bhd v Liew Fook Chuan
[1996] 1 MLJ 481
diikut.

(Oleh Edgar Joseph Jr HMP ) Kuasa yang boleh dilaksanakan oleh mahkamah ini ketika mendengar rayuan ini adalah, melalui
s 30 Akta Tafsiran 1948 dan 1967, kuasa-kuasa yang diperuntukkan oleh sub-s (4) s 69 AMK (dalam bentuk sebelum pindaan pada 24 Jun 1994 oleh
s 16(b) Akta Mahkamah Kehakiman (Pindaan) 1994 di mana perkataan-perkataan 'Mahkamah Rayuan' diganti untuk 'Mahkamah Agung') yang memberikan mahkamah ini kuasa bukan sahaja untuk membuat apa-apa perintah yang sepatutnya telah dibuat tetapi juga untuk membuat 'apa-apa perintah lanjutan atau perintah lain sebagaimana yang diperlukan oleh kes itu'. Kuasa-kuasa ini mencukupi bagi membolehkan mahkamah membuat pendapat bahawa Pekerja tersebut telah dipecat tanpa sebab atau alasan yang munasabah dan untuk membuat perintah berbangkit bagi pampasan adil (lihat ms 228C—E); Sungei Biak Tin Mines Ltd v Saw Choo Theng & Anor
[1970] 2 MLJ 226
diikut.

(Oleh Edgar Joseph Jr HMP ) Berhubung dengan soalan sama ada Pekerja tersebut telah dipecat atas sebab atau alasan yang munasabah, pengataan oleh Pekerja tersebut yang dibuat atas afidavit bahawa pemberhentian perkhidmatannya yang dikatakan melalui surat walaupun kononnya menurut pelaksanaan lebihan sebenarnya adalah suatu muslihat untuk menyelubungi pelaksanaan kuasa mala fide – dan oleh itu keputusan Mahkamah Perusahaan bahawa beliau telah dipecat atas sebab atau alasan yang munasabah adalah 'ketara salah dan jelas bertentangan' – tidak dicabar oleh Majikan tersebut melalui afidavit balas, dengan keputusan bahawa pengataan tersebut sepatutnya dianggap diterima. Dalam keadaan begitu, di mana mata pencarian seseorang terbabit, Pekerja tersebut tidak harus didedahkan kepada ancaman, kecemasan dan kelewatan prosiding di depan sebuah tribunal yang baru ditubuhkan dan justeru itu, kepada risiko penyalahgunaan undang-undang (lihat ms 229E—F dan 231B).

(Oleh Edgar Joseph Jr HMP ) Walau bagaimanapun, pada penghujung hujah mengenai bahagian kes ini, ahli Mahkamah ini yang membentuk majoriti berpuas hati, atas keseluruhan keterangan yang menonjol di Rekod Rayuan, bahawa Award Mahkamah Perusahaan adalah cacat atas alasan ketidakmunasabahan Wednesbury dan bahawa Pekerja tersebut telah dipecat tanpa sebab atau alasan yang munasabah (lihat ms 231C).

(Oleh Edgar Joseph Jr HMP ) Berhubung dengan kritikan bahawa adalah tidak wajar untuk Mahkamah ini membuat perintah berbangkit berkenaan oleh kerana persoalan sama ada Pekerja tersebut harus dikembalikan jawatan atau dibayar pampasan adalah persoalan fakta bagi penentuan Mahkamah Perusahaan dan bukan Mahkamah ini, kritikan tidak mengendahkan hujah bahawa di hadapan Mahkamah ini, peguam untuk Pekerja tersebut telah membatasi hujahannya kepada isu pampasan. Oleh itu, tiada perintah lain kecuali yang berkaitan dengan pampasan adalah wajar dan dengan itu pengembalian kedudukan jawatan tidak lagi menjadi isu (lihat ms 232A).

(Oleh Edgar Joseph Jr HMP ) Dalam mempertimbangkan persoalan sama ada relief berbangkit patut diberikan, hujah ditegaskan bahawa kesemua bukti material untuk tujuan menaksir pampasan wang yang harus dibayar adalah di hadapan Mahkamah, dan oleh kerana tiadanya cadangan bertentangan oleh peguam untuk Majikan tersebut, apa yang perlu adalah pengiraan aritmetik yang mudah bagi mengelakkan perlanjutan prosiding yang keterlaluan (lihat ms 231F—G).

(Oleh Edgar Joseph Jr HMP ) Adalah sukar untuk melihat bagaimana Pekerja tersebut boleh dikritik kerana beliau memilih untuk meneruskan tindakan melalui Kajian Semula Kehakiman di bawah A 53 dan bukan melalui Rujukan mengenai persoalan undang-undang di bawah s 33A Akta tersebut. Berbeza dengan Rujukan di bawah s 33A, Kajian Semula Kehakiman merupakan bidang kuasa budi bicara. Tidak satu daripada rintangan budi bicara terpakai kepada prosiding Rujukan di bawah s 33A (lihat ms 235H dan 236A, E).

(Oleh Edgar Joseph Jr HMP ) Berhubung dengan kritikan atas pergantungan pada kuasa sedia ada Mahkamah Tinggi, adalah disetujui bahawa Mahkamah tidak bebas menggunakan kuasa sedia adanya dengan melanggar peruntukan statutori. Namun demikian, Mahkamah tidak dapat bersetuju dengan cadangan bahawa penggunaan kuasa-kuasa harus dibataskan kepada keadaan di mana Parlimen telah tertinggal memperuntukkan dalam Akta (berkenaan) apa yang nyata sekali sepatutnya dimasukkan. Ciri, takat, dasar juridikal dan kaitan antara bidang kuasa sedia ada dan kaedah mahkamah telah dinyatakan dengan betul oleh Sir Jack Jacob QC, Senior Master of the Supreme Court dalam artikelnya, 'The Inherent Jurisdiction of the Court' [1970] Current Legal Problems 23 (lihat ms 237B—C).

(Oleh Edgar Joseph Jr HMP ) Aturan 92 k 4 merupakan suatu kaedah mahkamah yang unik, sebab walaupun ia tidak mentafsir atau memberi bidang kuasa, namun ia berfungsi sebagai peringatan dan pengesahan kuasa common law mahkamah, yang adalah kuasa bakian atau kuasa simpanan dan merupakan suatu sumber bidang kuasa yang berasingan dan berbeza daripada kuasa mahkamah. Dalam ertikata lain, jikapun tidak terdapat A 92 k 4, kuasa sedia ada Mahkamah Tinggi masih wujud (lihat ms 238I dan 239A—B).]

p.text: On 22 March 1995, we had quashed the order of the Industrial Court with costs to the appellant here and below, and adjourned this appeal for further arguments to 1 April 1995 on consequential reliefs.

The appellant ('the claimant') was first employed by the second respondent, the Malaysian Co-operative Consumer Society Ltd ('the society') on 5 May 1986 as Trainee General Manager at a salary of RM5,500 per month plus a car for his use. He was dismissed by the society on 31 January 1987. After an intervention by the Registrar of Societies under Part V of the
Industrial Relations Act 1967 ('the Act') he was re-employed by the society as Credit Control and Divisional Manager effective on 1 April 1987 but with a reduced salary of RM3,950 per month plus a car.

But the claimant was again dismissed on 30 April 1988 vide the society's letter dated 20 April 1988 ('the second dismissal'). At the time of his second dismissal, he was the Senior Divisional Manager (Debt Recovery and Credit Control).

The claimant made a representation to the Director General for Industrial Relations under s 20(1) of the Act, claiming that he was dismissed by the society without just cause or excuse, and asking that he be reinstated to his former post, failing which he should be entitled to reasonable compensation for loss of earnings, etc.
The Minister of Labour, acting under s 20(3) of the Act referred the claimant's representation to the Industrial Court for an Award.
After hearing the case, the Industrial Court made an Award on 16�September 1991 vide Award No 278 of 1991, wherein the Industrial Court held that the claimant was dismissed with just cause or excuse.
The reason for the dismissal of the claimant by the society was contained in the letter of dismissal dated 20 April 1988 and was as follows:

Taking into account the financial and economic loses and economic recession suffered by the society and in line with the decision of the Board of MCCS on 11 April 1988 to close the Debt Recovery and Credit Control Division, I am directed by the Board to terminate your employment as Senior Division Manager (Debt Recovery and Credit Control) with the society by giving you three months' salary in lieu of notice in accordance with reg 25(1) of the Society's Staff Rules and Regulations. Your last day of service shall be 30 April 1988.
The claimant in his statement of case before the Industrial Court raised the issue of bias and pleaded in paras 2(d) and 4(a)—4(c) as follows:
2(d) The claimant contends that he was a victim of partiality and vindictiveness by the CEO and the Chairman of the Society for the reasons appearing in paras 3 and 4 of this statement.

4(a) Encik Shamsudin had set his mind to get rid of the claimant for obvious reasons , ie knowing that the claimant was not appointed as CEO he would be a threat to the position of En Shamsudin if the claimant was retained in the society. He quickly succeeded in removing the claimant by having the Chairman and some directors, under his control.

4(b) The claimants' services were again terminated on 30 April 1988 within a duration of one year after the reinstatement in April 1987. The treatment given to the claimant, a family man in his mid forties, was like child-play. Copies of the letter written by the CEO to the claimant and the claimant's reply dated 19 February 1988 marked 'RR 9' and 'RR 10' respectively are annexed hereto which exposes the predetermined mind of En Shamsudin to get rid of the claimant though the matters in the letter of warning from the CEO to the claimant were simply trivial.

4(c) The claimant during the course of his duties had discovered many abuses of the society's funds and authority particularly matters relating to: (1) MA Pools for which En Shamsudin approved funds without the Board's sanction, (2) Sale of St Michaels franchise which was signed off by the Chairman without much concern for the interests of the society, and (3) the Komart fiasco for which Mr Mathimugam and the Board is accountable to the members. The claimant's attempts to seek explanations on these abuses were never liked by the CEO and the Chairman. A copy of the STAR newspaper cutting on this matter is annexed hereto and marked 'RR 11'. The police has since taken statement from the claimant on these matters (Emphasis added.)
What are the functions of the Industrial Court? We need only refer to three authorities.

In Goon Kwee Phoy & Ors v J & P Coats (M) Bhd
[1981] 2 MLJ 129 at p 136
, Raja Azlan Shah CJM (as he then was) held:

… Where representations are made and are referred to the Industrial Court for enquiry, it is the duty of the court to determine whether the termination or dismissal is with or without just cause or excuse.

The same learned judge held in Hotel Malaya Sdn Bhd & Anor v National Union of Hotel Bar and Restaurant Workers & Anor
[1982] 2 MLJ 237 at p 240
:
… Its functions comprise an investigation of the facts, and lastly the application of the law to those findings.

In L Michael & Anor v M/s Johnson Pumps India Ltd
[1975] 1 LLJ 262 at p 268
, the Supreme Court of India held:

The tribunal has the power and, indeed the duty to X-ray the [termination] order and discover its true nature, if the object and effect, if the attendant circumstances and the ulterior purpose to dismiss the Employee because he is an evil to be eliminated. But if the management, to cover up the inability to establish by an enquiry, illegitimately but ingeniously passes an innocent-looking order of termination simpliciter, such action is bad and is liable to be set aside.
It is clear that the claimant, had in his statement of case before the Industrial Court, raised the issue of bias, although the word 'bias' was not actually used.
The Industrial Court should have considered the following:
that the claimant was originally employed as Trainee General Manager at a salary of RM5,500 per month;
that he was dismissed;
that he was re-employed after the intervention by the Registrar of Society;
that he was re-employed as a divisional manager with lesser salary of RM 3,950 pm;
that despite the lower position and lower salary the claimant did not refuse to accept the re-employment;

that the claimant had questioned the abuses and malpractices of his senior in office and that because of this the society felt that it was dangerous to have him in the society, and therefore was determined to get rid of him.

Had the Industrial Court considered these allegations, it may have come to a different conclusion as to the genuineness of the reasons given by the society for the second dismissal of the claimant's employment.

The notes of proceedings of the Industrial Court show that within one (1) month after the claimant's dismissal, another executive ('Shakeeb') who was junior to the claimant was appointed General Manager Business Development which was one of the functions performed by the claimant. This is prima facie evidence that the reasons given for the termination of the claimant's services in the society's letter dated 20 April 1988 were not genuine and that the purported termination was mala fide. The Industrial Court failed to address its mind to this issue and committed one of the errors highlighted in the case of Kesatuan Pekerja-pekerja Perusahaan Logam & Anor v The Honourable Minister of Labour, Malaysia
[1991] 3 CLJ 2164 at p 2165
, that is:
He must call his own attention to the matters he is bound to consider.

But we find that the Industrial Court in its Award did not at all address its mind to the issue of bias raised by the claimant which, in our view, is the central pillar of his case. The failure of the Industrial Court to address its mind to this fundamental issue is a serious error which affects jurisdiction and which will result in the Award being quashed.

We also note that the society in its statement in reply before the Industrial Court had raised four allegations of misconduct, and in the course of the proceedings before the Industrial Court had even raised two further allegations of misconduct against the claimant. The claimant in his written submission before the Industrial Court had dealt at length with these six allegations of misconduct. However, the society in its reply had totally ignored and did not at all respond to the claimant's answer to these six allegations of misconduct. The Industrial Court in its Award had misdirected itself by not considering the issues raised, in particular, it had failed to determine as a fact whether the termination was as a result of a retrenchment exercise or, as a result of the claimant's misconduct.

It is trite law that a party is bound by its pleadings. The Industrial Court must scrutinize the pleadings and identify the issues, take evidence, hear the parties' arguments and finally pronounce its judgment having strict regards to the issues. It is true that the Industrial Court is not bound by all the technicalities of a civil court ( s 30 of the Act) but it must follow the same general pattern. The object of pleadings is to determine what are the issues and to narrow the area of conflict. The Industrial Court cannot ignore the pleadings and treat them as mere pedantry or formalism, because if it does so, it may lose sight of the issues, admit evidence irrelevant to the issues or reject evidence relevant to the issues and come to the wrong conclusion. The Industrial Court must at all times keep itself alert to the issues and attend to matters it is bound to consider. In this case, the Industrial Court had totally failed to consider the allegations of misconduct but simply concluded that because the letter of termination was grounded on retrenchment exercise, it is not bound, and therefore, not obliged to consider the issues of bias and misconduct.

For the reasons given we unanimously found that the Industrial Court had come to the wrong conclusion when it decided that the claimant was dismissed with just cause and excuse, and the Award must, therefore, be quashed.

The learned counsel for the claimant submitted that although ordinarily the court after quashing the Award of the Industrial Court would remit the case to the Industrial Court with a direction to make the necessary consequential orders, in the present case we ought ourselves to determine and make the appropriate consequential orders. We found that although the learned counsel for the claimant was prepared to argue this point, the learned counsel for the respondent was somewhat taken by surprise, and to enable him to prepare his arguments, we adjourned the hearing to 1 April 1995.

On the resumed hearing, the learned counsel for the claimant submitted that the claimant is now 51 years old. He has no professional qualifications. At p 234 of the Appeal Record, the claimant had submitted as follows, and was not denied or challenged by the society:

The claimant has spent his entire working life in the co-operative movement. He worked for the Koperative LLN for 23 years and his record of service was impeccable. He left Koperatif LLN for a challenging career with the society. He has even taken a lower salary from RM5,500 as Trainee General Manager to the salary of RM3,950 as Senior Divisional Manager Debt Recovery and Credit Control. Even with this lower salary, the society had treated the claimant very unjustly, and retained two retired pensioners as managers in the society.

In para (5) of his statement of case before the Industrial Court, the claimant had claimed reinstatement to his former position without loss of remuneration, service, seniority and benefits of any kind, failing which, to reasonable compensation for loss of earnings and loss of substantial gratuity, higher rates of Employees Provident Fund, deprivation of housing loan and other benefits, etc.

The learned counsel for the respondent submitted that, in the event of the appeal being allowed, this court has no jurisdiction to make an order for consequential relief, and that we can only make an order remitting the case back to the Industrial Court for consequential reliefs. Learned counsel for the claimant submitted that the claimant is now jobless, and, while the society can certainly afford it financially to have the case remitted to the Industrial Court for consequential reliefs, the claimant could not afford to do so. Besides, if the case is remitted to the Industrial Court for consequential reliefs, it may take another six to seven years before the case can be concluded. The claimant may die first in which event his claim will have to be abandoned. He, therefore, submitted that we have the jurisdiction to order consequential relief and should not send the claimant away from the court of justice empty handed.

The case of Navinchandra Shakerchand Shah v Ahmedabad Co-operative Department Stores Ltd
[1979] 1 LLJ 60 at p 77
defined the meaning of 'consequential relief' as follows:

Consequential relief is ancillary to the main relief. That is why it is called consequential. The main relief that is sought in a writ of certiorari is that a quasi judicial tribunal has either failed to exercise the jurisdiction vested in it or has acted in excess of it and that order has caused some harm to the petitioner and he seeks relief. The relief as the main relief that can be given to him is to quash the order but more often it is found that that hardly ameliorates or improves the position of the petitioner. Therefore, consequential order has always to be made and power to grant the main relief would unless a contrary intention is somewhere expressed imply the power to grant consequential relief.
Five cases were submitted to us by the learned counsel for the respondent in support of his argument. We have considered these cases and they are:

R v Barnet London Borough Council, ex p Nilish Shah
[1983] 2 AC 309
involved an issue of five immigrant students who had no right of abode in the United Kingdom and applied for an Award under s 1 of the Education Act 1962 (UK). The House of Lords ordered certiorari and mandamus and remitted the case to the local education authority.
We note that this is not a case of a workman's right to his job and livelihood which is of a fundamental importance.

Attorney General of Hong Kong v Ng Yuen Shiu
[1983] 2 AC 629
involved a Chinese who entered Hong Kong illegally from Macau in 1967. In 1976, he was removed to Macau but re-entered illegally shortly afterwards and remained in Hong Kong. A removal order was made against him without giving him an opportunity of making any representations as to why he should not be removed.
The principles of law involving the removal of an illegal immigrant considered in that case cannot be applied to industrial law cases

Regina v Tower Hamlets London Borough Council, ex p Chetnik Developments Ltd
[1988] 1 AC 858
involved the question of payment of rates under the General Rate Act 1967, and has no application to the present case.

Regina v Immigration Appeal Tribunal, ex p Bakhtaur Singh
[1986] 1 WLR 910
involved a deportation order made by the Secretary of State against an Indian citizen. This is an immigration case which was remitted back to the Immigration Appeal Tribunal to consider the matter de novo.

Chief Constable of the North Wales Police v Evans
[1982] 1 WLR 1155
involved the dismissal of a probationary police constable under the Police Regulations 1971. At p 1176, Lord Brightman said:

I feel that the choice of remedy is a difficult one. It is a matter of discretion. From the point of view of the respondent who has been wronged in a matter so vital to his life, an order of mandamus is the only satisfactory remedy. I have been much tempted to suggest to your Lordships that it would be in the circumstances be a remedy proper to be granted . But it is unusual, in a case such as the present, for the court to make an order of mandamus, and I think that in practice it might border on usurpation of the powers of the chief constable, which is to be avoided. With some reluctance and hesitation, I feel that the respondent will have to content himself with the less satisfactory declaration that I have outlined. (Emphasis added.)
However, it must be noted that at p 1172, Lord Brightman held:

My Lords, I must address myself later to the question of remedy. All that I would say at this moment is that it would, to my mind, be regrettable if a litigant who establishes that he has been legally wronged, and particularly in so important a matter as the pursuit of his chosen profession, has to be sent away from a court of justice empty-handed save for an order for the recoupment of the expense to which he has been put in establishing a barren victory. (Emphasis added.)

I noted that in this case the police constable had a remedy granted because the counsel for the Chief Constable told their Lordships that the police constable would be offered monetary compensation and therefore there was a consequential remedy given to the police constable. He did not leave the court empty-handed with a barren victory. At pp 1175 and 1176, it was made clear that:

Counsel for the Appellant acting on instructions, told your Lordships that if the decision of your Lordships' House went in favour of the respondent it would be the intention of the North Wales Police to offer him monetary compensation . I trust that the compensation which the chief constable has in mind to offer would be on a generous scale, and amply reflect the fact that the respondent has been unlawfully deprived of his profession as a consequence of the wrongful procedures of the chief constable's predecessor in office.

The learned counsel for the appellant submitted to us a bundle of authorities to support his contention that although a decision of the Industrial Court is made final by law, the High Court when exercising its supervisory jurisdiction has the power not only to quash the order made by the Industrial Court but to pass substantive orders in place of the order it has quashed or set aside. In other words, the jurisdiction of the High Court is not only confined to the narrow precints of quashing the impugned order on certiorari but it can also modulate its order so as to grant the appropriate relief because the jurisdiction of the High Court does not end as soon as the impugned order is quashed.

In Gujarat Steel Tubes Ltd & Ors v GS Tubes Mazdoor Sabha & Ors
[1980] 2 SCC 593, the Supreme Court of India while quashing the order of dismissal ordered reinstatement to some workers and compensation to other workers. At p 624 of that case, the Supreme Court stated:

While the remedy under art 226 is extraordinary and is of Anglo Saxon vintage, it is not a carbon copy of the English processes. Article 226 is a sparing surgery but the lancet operates where injustice suppurates. While traditional restraints like availability of alternative remedy hold back the court, andjudicial power should not ordinarily rush in where the other two branches fear to tread, judicial daring is not daunted where glaring injustice demands even affirmative action.

In Management of City of Bangalore Municipal Corp Employer Co-operative Society Ltd v EV Raju
[1987] 1 LLJ 22
, the court held:

The next point for consideration is whether the matter has to go back to the labour court with a direction to appreciate the evidence on record and record its finding on the misconduct alleged against the workman. Ordinarily, I would have made a direction on these lines, but after a lapse of nearly ten years from the date of termination of the services of the workman, the interests of justice would not warrant the remand of this matter to the labour court.

I note that art 226 of the Indian Constitution empowers the High Court to issue directions, orders or writs in the nature of habeas corpus, mandamus, prohibition, quo warranto and certiorari or any of them. Such directions, orders or writ may be issued for the enforcement of fundamental rights or for any other purpose.

In Malaysia, the High Courts are conferred with similar powers by para 1 of the Schedule to the
Courts of Judicature Act 1964 which states:

Power to issue to any person or authority directions, orders or writs, including writs of the nature of habeas corpus, mandamus, prohibition, quo warranto and certiorari, or any others, for the enforcement of the rights conferred by Part II of the Constitution, or any of them, or for any purpose.

The procedure relating to an application for certiorari is laid out in O 53 of the
Rules of the High Court 1980 .

I cannot find any provision in the
Courts of Judicature Act 1964 , the
Rules of the High Court 1980 or the Act expressly or impliedly prohibiting the High Court from granting any relief as provided for in the Act when quashing an Award of the Industrial Court.
