(3) Where any party against whom an interim order, whether by way of injunction or stay or in any other manner, is made on, or in any proceedings relating to, a petition under cl (1), without–
(a) furnishing to such party copies of such petition and all documents in support of the plea for such interim order, and

(b) giving such party an opportunity of being heard, makes an application to the High Court for the vacation of such order and furnishes a copy of such application to the party in whose favour such order has been made or the counsel of such party, the High Court shall dispose of the application within a period of two weeks from the date on which it is received or from the date on which the copy of such application is so furnished, whichever is later, or where the High Court is closed on the last day of that period, before the expiry of the next day afterwards on which the High Court is open; and if the application is not so disposed of, the interim order shall, on the expiry of that period, or, as the case may be, the expiry of the said next day, stand vacated.
(4) The power conferred on a High Court by this article shall not be in derogation of the power conferred on the Supreme Court by cl (2) of Art 32.

p.text: (1) Without prejudice to the generality of Art 121 of the Constitution the High Court shall in the exercise of its jurisdiction have all the powers which were vested in it immediately prior to Malaysia Day and such other powers as may be vested in it by any written law in force within its local jurisdiction.
(2) Without prejudice to the generality of sub-s (1) the High Court shall have the additional powers set out in the Schedule:
Provided that all such powers shall be exercised in accordance with any written law or rules of court relating to the same.

text.emph: Paragraph (1) to the Schedule of the Courts of Judicature Act 1964

p.text: Power to issue to any person or authority directions, orders or writs, including writs of the nature of habeas corpus, mandamus, prohibition, quo warranto and certiorari, or any others, for the enforcement of the rights conferred by Part II of the Constitution, or any of them or for any purpose.

I would agree that there is similarity in the language of that part of art�226(1) on jurisdiction to issue writs, etc with the Schedule, and that Pt III of the Indian Constitution deals with fundamental rights as in Pt�II of our Constitution. However, on proper reading of the two provisions I am inclined to the view that the jurisdictional authority conferred by the two laws differ substantially in their application.

Article 226 confers vast and wider powers to the Supreme and High Courts in India than those under
s 25 of the Courts of Judicature Act 1964 does to our courts. Read with art 32 of the Constitution of India, the Supreme and High Courts there are empowered to hear directly as original jurisdiction any application where the issue is on the infringement of the fundamental right of the subject.

Under arts 226 and 32, the powers of the High Courts in India are not limited to the issuance of writs in the nature of the English prerogative writs alone but the court could also give directions requiring affirmative action or positive activity whereas in the corresponding English writ the court could only set aside the order complained of – see Calcutta Gas Co v State of WBA
1952 SC 1044
. Indeed, under art 226, the High Courts in India can give consequential relief – see State of Madhya Pradesh v Bhailal Bhai
AIR 1964 SC 1006
.

Having regard to the vast and almost unlimited powers of art 226, the question to be answered is whether our courts are entitled on the basis of minor similarity of the language in one of the articles alone to import into our
Courts of Judicature Act the jurisdiction envisaged in that article. I am not in favour of such an interpretation for the following considerations:

Article 226 is part of the Constitution of India, ie the supreme law of that country. Being a provision entrenched in the constitution the powers therein, including the power to issue the writ of certiorari, cannot be taken away or in any manner modified, other than by an amendment to the Constitution itself. Hence, any law which tends to take away or restrict the jurisdiction of the court under art 226 must be held to be void and so the courts in India are entitled to exercise the powers under that article free from any fetters imposed directly or indirectly. In contrast, our court's power to issue certiorari is contained in an ordinary Act of Parliament and therefore it can be qualified or modified by another Act of Parliament. Particularly, in our case is our
Rules of the High Court 1980 .

The powers under art 226 include not only the power to issue writs in the nature of English prerogative writs but also the power to issue directions and orders for the enforcement thereof. The powers are exercisable even against the Government or any public official acting on behalf of the Government. The position in England is otherwise. Mandamus does not issue to the Crown or any public servant acting for the Crown. Thus the power under the article is much wider and part of which are outside the ambit of the English prerogative writs. As our certiorari laws are similarly modelled as the pre-1977 amendment of the English Rules of the Supreme Court hence the power to grant consequential relief under the article is likewise outside the scope of our
Rules of the High Court .

Despite the vast powers conferred by art 226, the courts in India have always exercised these powers with self restraint or self imposed limitations so as not to impede the public administration of that country. Thus the large power conferred on the Supreme Court and High Court under arts 32 and 226 are exercised in accordance with well established principles. For instance, when exercising its discretionary jurisdiction under this article, the High Court should not act as a court of appeal or revision in order to rectify mere errors on facts. The article was not intended for use to obtain alternative remedy which could be obtained by a suit or other statutory remedy. When it is open to the aggrieved person to obtain from a tribunal set up for a specific purpose or as provided in a statute, the courts will not entertain the application, if by doing so it would by-pass the machinery specially created by statute to determine such a dispute. Likewise, the courts in India will not enter into determination of questions which require elaborate examination of evidence – Thansingh v Supdt of Taxes
AIR 1964 SC 1419
at 1423 (7), and in DLF Housing Construction (P) Ltd v Delhi Municipal Corp & Ors
AIR 1976 SC 386
at p 392 , Goswami J expressed it as follows:

In our opinion, in a case where the basic facts are disputed, and complicated questions of law and fact depending on evidence are involved the writ court is not the proper forum for seeking relief. The right course for the High Court to follow was to dismiss the writ petition on this preliminary ground, without entering upon the merits of the case. In the absence of firm and adequate factual foundation, it was hazardous to embark upon a determination of the points involved. On this short ground while setting aside the findings of the High Court, we would dismiss both the writ petition and the appeal with costs. The appellants may if so advised, seek their remedy by a regular suit.

Although Art 226 is a much wider provision than the corresponding power of English prerogative writs, the courts in India have adopted the nomenclature of the English writs and so the principles of English law has been applied in application made under the article. In Carlsbad Mineral Water Manufacturing Co v Jagtiani
AIR 1952 Cal 315
, the High Court observed:

'… At first sight it would appear that the language used in Art 226 imposes no limits whatsoever as to the category of persons to whom, and the purpose for which orders or writs, including writs in the nature of habeas corpus, mandamus, prohibition, quo warranto and certiorari or any of them, may be issued by the High Court. But once the origin and history of high prerogative writs are remembered, it is clear that the powers given to a High Court under Art 226 are to be exercised in accordance with the principles which governed the said writs. The power of the High Court to issue such a writ 'to any person' can only mean the power to issue such a writ to any person to whom according to well-established principles a writ lay. That a writ may issue to an appropriate person for the enforcement of any of the rights conferred by Part III is clear enough from the language used. But the words 'and for any other purpose' must mean 'for any other purpose for which any of the writs mentioned would according to well established principle issue.'

So was it in Janardhan Reddy v State of Hyderbad
AIR 1951 SC 217
where the Supreme Court observed:
The power given to this court under this provision is a large one but it has to be exercised in accordance with well established principles.
Hence, the principles of English law are applicable to issue of writs under Art 226 to the extent that they do not conflict with the provision of the Constitution of India.

The existence of alternative remedy and the exercise of discretionary relief are matters seriously considered by the Indian High Court in granting relief under Art 226. In a certiorari case, the right to a rehearing and assessment of compensation by a specialised tribunal is a statutory alternative remedy.

Thus, in the case of Veluswami v Raja Nainar
AIR 1959 SC 422
, the court observed (at p 423):

The jurisdiction of the High Court to issue the writs against orders of the tribunal is undoubted; but then it is well settled that where there is another remedy provided, the court may properly exercise its discretion in refusing to interfere under Art 226.

Likewise, where the case involves the exercise of discretion by a tribunal entrusted to do so by the law, the Supreme and High Courts cannot arrogate that discretion and on their own pass an order on the merits. This was the rationale laid down by the Supreme Court of India in Veerappa Pillai v Raman & Raman Ltd
AIR 1952 SC 192
during which Chandrasekhara Aiyar J said (at pp 195-196):

Such writs as are referred to in Art 226 are obviously intended to enable the High Court to issue them in grave cases where the subordinate tribunals or bodies or officers act wholly without jurisdiction, or in excess of it, or in violation of the principles of natural justice, or refuse to exercise a jurisdiction vested in them, or there is an error apparent on the face of the record, and such act, omission, error, or excess has resulted in manifest injustice. However extensive the jurisdiction may be, it seems to us that it is not so wide or large as to enable the High Court to convert itself into a court of appeal and examine for itself the correctness of the decisions impugned and decide what is the proper view to be taken or the order to be made.

Further, it will be noticed that the High Court here did not content itself with merely quashing the proceedings, it went further and directed the Regional Transport Authority, Tanjore, 'to grant to the petitioner permits in respect of the five buses in respect of which a joint application was made originally by the petitioner and Balasubramania Pillai and that in case the above buses have been condemned, the petitioner shall be at liberty to provide substitutes within such times as may be prescribed by the authorities'. Such a direction was clearly in excess of its powers and jurisdiction.

Although the decision in Veerappa 's case had been distinguished in Bhailal v Additional Commissioner, Akola
AIR 1953 Nagpur 89
, the distinguishing question is confined to the right of the High Court to issue direction to the Rent Control Authority to grant permission to the petitioner to determine the tenancy. The Nagpur case (ibid) is therefore not an authority to sanction the courts into assuming the role of a fact finder and to make orders on the merits of its own findings.

Although the High and Supreme Courts in India have the jurisdiction to grant consequential relief, these courts have very rarely exercised those powers. The Gujarat Steel case is an exceptional case involving several hundred people in an industrial dispute of a steel mill and which requires exigent solution for obvious economic reasons. The precept of referring to judgments based on foreign Constitution or Acts of Parliament is to be resorted to with greatest caution. Even in construing an Act of Parliament within the same state, such a course should only be taken where there is ambiguity. In The Queen v Titterton
[1895] 2 QB 61 at p 67
, Lord Russell CJ said:

But Mr Sutton has referred us to two cases as authorities in support of his contention that s 47 of the Act of 1839 is still unrepealed, and holds good in such a case as the present. With regard to those cases, I may observe that the language of Lord Campbell CJ in one of them ( Wray v Ellis
1 E & E 276
at p 288 ), where he says that 'there can be little use in referring to cases where a similar question has arisen on Acts of Parliament differently framed, for they only illustrate the general principle which is not in dispute,' seems most apposite to the present discussion. The duty of the court when called upon to construe an Act of Parliament is, I conceive to read the Act itself, and if its language is clear to give effect to what the legislature has said. It is to my mind proper to refer to earlier Acts in pari materia only where there is ambiguity. And I can see no ambiguity here.

In our present case, the original orders prayed for was for a reinstatement. Reinstatement is a primary remedy involving the exercise of discretion and discretion must be exercised along recognized lines. Thus in judgment of Sangram Singh v Election Tribunal
[1955] 2 SCR l
; AIR 1955 SC 425
, it was stated:

The High Courts do not, and should not, act as courts of appeal under art�226. Their powers are purely discretionary and though no limits can be placed upon that discretion it must be exercised along recognized lines and not arbitrarily; and one of the limitations imposed by the courts on themselves is that they will not exercise jurisdiction in this class of case unless substantial injustice has ensued, or is likely to ensue. They will not allow themselves to be turned into courts of appeal or revision to set right mere errors of law which do not occasion injustice in a broad and general sense, for, though no legislature can impose limitations on these constitutional powers it is a sound exercise of discretion to bear in mind the policy of the legislature to have disputes about these special rights decided as speedily as may be. Therefore, writ petitions should not be lightly entertained in this class of case.

The discretion as to whether to award compensation in lieu of reinstatement is an issue to be decided by the Industrial Court – see Dr A Dutt v Assunta Hospital
[1981] 1 MLJ 304 at p 313
, where Chang Min Tat FJ – who delivered the judgment of the Federal Court – said:

With all respect, this interpretation clearly flies in the teeth of the plain provisions of sub-ss (1), (5) and (6). It ignores the jurisdiction given to the court (Semble – Industrial Court) to make an Award 'relating to all or any of the issues in dispute.' The right to compensation must be an issue in representations for reinstatement and necessarily arises where the court would not order reinstatement. And this is apart from the duty of the court to act according to 'equity, good conscience and the substantial merits of the case without regard to technicalities and legal form.' 'The court shall not be restricted to the specific relief claimed' must, in the case of representations for reinstatement under s 20(1), which we have observed is the logical claim to be made by the workman, mean an Award not only in addition to the order for reinstatement, but also in compensation for the reinstatement that the court would not Award. Confirmation for this interpretation can be found in the subsequent words 'may include in the Award any matter or thing which it thinks necessary or expedient for the purpose of settling … the reference to it under s 20(3).' We cannot understand how in a reference under s 20(3) an 'Award' that orders neither reinstatement nor compensation where the dismissal is without just cause or excuse, can be said to be in accordance with the guidelines in sub-ss (1), (5) and (6) or settle the reference.

The determination on reinstatement or compensation is an issue of fact which may require technical knowledge, the exercise of administrative experience and discretion. Often it involves various considerations of the workman's background, his relationship with his employer, the suitability of reinstating him in his former office and many intricate facts relating to his employment. In assuming his pecuniary loss brought about by the dismissal, it would be necessary for the Industrial Court to decide on the evidence rather than on affidavit alone. The Federal Court, in our present case, would be performing its original and appellate but not its supervisory jurisdiction if we were to proceed to determine the issues on the appellant's compensation in lieu of reinstatement.

Having regard to the contrasting nature of jurisdiction envisaged under art 226 of the Constitution of India and
s 25(2) of our Courts of Judicature Act 1964, the cautious attitude of the Indian courts in exercising the wider jurisdiction, the conflicting authorities with regard to the article itself and the various factor that have been discussed in paras (i)—(v) above, it would seem judicially inappropriate and unsound for this court to grant consequential remedy to the appellant beyond those contemplated by both our written law and judicial precedents.

Over and above these factors, it is my considered opinion that our
s�25 of the Courts of Judicature Act 1964 – being a mere creature of statute and not being part of the Federal Constitution – is subject to qualification and modification by other legislation. Section 25(2) must be read with O�53 of the
Rules of the High Court 1980 ; and when so read, the powers under the Act do not seem to be unlimited.

As can be seen from the Act reproduced earlier, the power to issue the writ in the nature of the English prerogative writs is derived from s�25(2) of the Act. The authority conferred by that subsection however must be read subject to the proviso following:
Provided that all such powers shall be exercised in accordance with any written law or rules of court relating to the same. (Emphasis added.)

It is patently obvious from the above that the Legislature has not only restricted the powers under s 25(2) to be exercised in conformity with any other existing legislation but it has also seen fit to specify the rules of court as being the law to which the proviso also applies.

The particular rule of court applicable in this instance is O 53 of the
Rules of the High Court 1980 . Under this order, certiorari may be issued to remove the record of the proceedings from an inferior court or administrative tribunal or other public authority to the High Court to be quashed. Under the pre-amended English O 53 which is identical to our O 53, there is no power to amend the proceeding – see Walsall Overseers v LNW Ry (1878) 4 App Cas 30 but there is power to quash and order retrial: R v Northumberland Compensation Appeal Tribunal
[1951] 1 KB 711
. The inescapable inference from this reasoning leads us to the conclusion that the power of review under certiorari must be exercised in conformity with the provision of O 53; and when so applied, the power to issue certiorari is confined only to the quashing of the order or remitting it to the inferior court or tribunal for retrial. Consequently, as the powers of our High Court are confined to quashing the inferior court's order and sending it back for retrial, the court cannot embark on the exercise for the determination of consequential remedies, neither can the Indian authorities based on the wider and positive provisions of their constitution be relied on to extend the jurisdiction of our courts beyond what was contemplated by our legislature.
That intention becomes apparent when one looks at the state of the relevant order prior to and after the coming into effect of both the Malaysian and English Rules of Court.

In 1977, the Rules of Supreme Court of England were amended to provide changes in the substance of the procedural law. Reliefs by way of mandamus, prohibition, certiorari, declaration and injunction have been consolidated under the generic caption of 'Judicial Review'. An applicant under this amended order can claim any or all of these reliefs in the alternative or in addition to other reliefs arising out of the same matter. Under this amended order, the courts in England are empowered to award damages – see O 53 r 7 SCP 199 p 845 and also the guide to commentary on Judicial Review 53/1–14/23. As a result of the amendment, an applicant would not fail on any of the technical grounds in case he had asked for the wrong writ and he has the added advantage of claiming relief by way of declaration or injunction.

However, when our Rules of the High Court was made in 1980, the startling departure from the common law made by the said 1977 amendment was not adopted in Malaysia in our
Rules of the High Court 1980 . The Rules Committee instead opted for the pre-amended order of the English Rules of the Supreme Court 1965 with necessary modification but otherwise reproduced substantially word for word O 53 r 6 of the English Rules corresponding to O 53 r 5 which now reads:

5(1) In the case of an application for an order certiorari to remove any proceedings for the purpose of their being quashed , the applicant may not question the validity of any order, warrant, commitment, conviction, inquisition or record unless before the hearing of the motion or summons he has served a copy thereof verified by affidavit on the Attorney General, or accounts for his failure to do so to the satisfaction of the Court or Judge hearing the motion or summons.
(2) Where an order of certiorari is made in any such case the order shall direct that the proceedings shall be quashed forthwith on their removal to the High Court. (Emphasis added.)

Thus, the power under our O 53 remains the same as it were in the English pre-amended order, that is certiorari is intended for the quashing of the lower court's or tribunal's proceedings and in appropriate cases to order a retrial, and nothing more.

It is patently conspicuous that the Committee has deliberately left out the power set out under O 53 r 7 of the English post-1977 order on damages or compensation as well as the alternative or additional relief as contained in that order entitled 'Application For Judicial Review' and therefore by doing so had manifested its intention that the supervisory jurisdiction of our High Court to prevent injustice in cases involving error of law on the face of the records, be confined to the calling up of the records and quashing the erroneous order of that court. If the Rules Committee had thought otherwise, there could have been nothing easier for them than to reproduce r 7 of post-1977 English order to give effect to consequential relief such as damages or compensation.

It might be suggested that the Rules Committee had overlooked this provision when they drew up the 1980 Rules, but such a thought would be clearly unsustainable when one proceeds to consider that the Rules Committee under
s 17 of the Courts of Judicature Act 1964 consists of no lesser personalities than the Lord President, the two Chief Justices of the High Courts (as they were then known), judges of the Federal and High Courts, the Attorney General, nominees of the Bar Council and prominent advocates and solicitors.

It would be preposterious to even think that they were being neglectful or unaware of the position of the English law which is contained in the White Book and to which almost every member of the Judiciary and the Bar makes constant reference.

To my mind, the omission to adopt r 7 of the post-1977 English Rules was done with a deliberate design to exclude our courts from indulging in the deliberation on consequential relief and thereby shut the flood gates to a new category of original or appellate jurisdiction on a Judicial Review.

In the words of Turner LJ in Hawkins v Gathercole
6 De GM & GI
; 43 ER 1129
:

The dominant purpose in construing a statute is to ascertain the intent of the Legislature, and this may be done in any one of three ways. First, by considering the cause and necessity of the Act. Secondly, by comparing one part of the Act with another; and, thirdly (and this is the most indefinite) sometimes by foreign (meaning extraneous) aids 'so far as they can justly be considered to throw light upon the subject'.

The intention of our legislature is manifest from the wordings of s 25 and our
Rules of the High Court 1980 and also by comparison with the pre and post-1977 English rules, that is, our O 53 is meant for quashing the lower court's or tribunal's order only and not for the court to take upon itself the original jurisdiction of deliberating on questions of reinstatement, damages or compensation.

For that reason, none of the certiorari cases on the 1977 pre-amended English law could have possibly allowed any additional claim for damages or compensation. The rule that a claim for certiorari could not be coupled with a claim for damages is so elementary that only one text book out of a number of those on similar subject took the trouble to mention that no claim for damages could be made in an application of certiorari – See Hood Phillips Constitutional and Administration Law (7th Ed, 1987).

Even after the amendment of the English O 53 there appears to be no decided cases where the High Court has gone into detailed computation of compensation. The indisposition of the English courts towards deliberating on the question of consequential remedy in Judicial Review is discernible from the following judgment of Lord Brightman in Chief Constable of the North Wales Police v Evans
[1982] 1 WLR 1155 at p 1173
:

I turn secondly to the proper purpose of the remedy of Judicial Review, what it is and what it is not. In my opinion, the law was correctly stated in the speech of Lord Evershed, at p 96. His was a dissenting judgment but the dissent was not concerned with this point. Lord Evershed referred to 'a danger of usurpation of power on the part of the courts … under the pretext of having regard to the principles of natural justice. He added:

'I do observe again that it is not the decision as such which is liable to review; it is only the circumstances in which the decision was reached, and particularly in such a case as the present the need for giving to the party dismissed an opportunity for putting his case.'

Judicial review is concerned, not with the decision, but with the decision-making process. Unless that restriction on the power of the court is observed, the court will in my view, under the guise of preventing the abuse of power, be itself guilty of usurping power.
and further at pp 1175 and 1176, His Lordship said:

It is possible that the respondent would not wish, nor indeed would have any incentive, to pursue a claim for damages. Counsel for the appellant acting on instructions, told your Lordships that if the decision of your Lordships' House went in favour of the respondent it would be the intention of the North Wales Police to offer him monetary compensation. I trust that the compensation which the chief constable has in mind to offer would be on a generous scale, and amply reflect the fact that the respondent has been unlawfully deprived of his profession as a consequence of the wrongful procedures of the chief constable's predecessor in office.

I feel that the choice of remedy is a difficult one. It is a matter of discretion. From the point of view of the respondent who has been wronged in a matter so vital to his life, an order of mandamus is the only satisfactory remedy. I have been much tempted to suggest to your Lordships that it would be the circumstances be a remedy proper to be granted. But it is unusual, in a case such as the present, for the court to make an order of mandamus, and I think that in practice it might border on usurpation of the powers of the chief constable, which is to be avoided.

The next argument from DatO' Lingam which also found favour in the learned Chief Justice's judgment is on O 92 r 4 of the
Rules of the High Court 1980 . Citations from two Malaysian cases were reproduced in the judgment. The first by Edgar Joseph J (as he then was) in Pacific Centre Sdn Bhd v United Engineers (M) Bhd
[1984] 2 MLJ 143 at p 147
read:

It is also clear that the inherent jurisdiction of the court includes all the powers that are necessary 'to fulfill itself as a court of law', 'to uphold, to protect and to fulfill the judicial function of administering justice according to law in a regular, orderly and effective manner' . (Emphasis added.)

I have no quarrel with the above comments by IH Jacob in his article entitled The Inherent Jurisdiction of the Court as published in the [1970] Current Law Problems. Indeed, I find this passage read in the light of his words 'according to law' to be suggestive of the writer's assertion that inherent powers should be exercised by the courts in compliance or consistent with the existing law.

It is interesting to note that the same author also maintained that the jurisdiction which is a complex one possesses several features viz, that it is part of procedural law, both civil and criminal, and not of substantive law (p 24) and that it is a concept which must be distinguished from the exercise of judicial discretion (p 25).

The second citation is taken from Re Application by Dunlop Estate Bhd, Dunlop Estates Bhd v All Malayan Estates Staff Union
[1980] 1 MLJ 243 at p 246
wherein Mohd Azmi J (as he then was) remarked:

In my view, having regard to the principles enunciated in the cases cited, the
Industrial Relations Act , being a social legislation enacted with the prime object of attaining social justice and industrial peace, demands practical and realistic interpretation whenever necessary , for the purpose of maintaining good relationship and fair dealings between employers and workers and their trade union, and the settlement of any differences or disputes arising from their relationship.

The citation, as I see it, is a general remark on the interpretation of
s 30(7) of the Industrial Relations Act 1967 rather than on the inherent powers of the court and so is the next cited case, ie Nothman v Barnet London Borough Council
[1978] 1 WLR 220
which deal with purposive approach in interpretation of statute rather than the characteristics of the inherent powers of the court.

Proceeding on the basis of Jacob's features of inherent jurisdiction and other judicial precedents, it would appear that the court cannot enlarge the power to provide remedy in addition to or in contrast with those already prescribed under any substantive law.

That attitude of the English courts to leave the matter of relief to be worked out by the lower tribunals is further illustrated by several post amendment cases such as Barnet London Borough Council, ex p Nilish Shah [1983] 2 AC 309; Attorney General of Hong Kong v Ng Yuen Shiu
[1983] 2 AC 629
; Regina v Tower Hamlets London Borough Council, ex p Chetnik Development Ltd
[1968] 1 AC 858
and Regina v Immigration Appeal Tribunal, ex p Bakhtuar Singh
[1986] 1 WLR 910
, all of these authorities, although they do not arise out of industrial dispute, nevertheless deal with the principle applicable generally to relief in application for Judicial Review.

Thus, in Permodalan MBf Sdn Bhd v Tan Sri Datuk Sri Hamzah bin Abu Samah & Ors
[1988] 1 MLJ 178
, Syed Agil Barakbah SCJ when delivering the judgment of the Federal Court said at p 181:

Has the court any jurisdiction to exercise its inherent powers in the instant case?
Order 92 r 4 of the RHC provides:

4 For the removal of doubts it is hereby declared that nothing in these rules shall be deemed to limit or affect the inherent powers of the court to make any order as may be necessary to prevent injustice or to prevent an abuse of the process of the court.

We read this to mean that the rules cannot interfere with the exercise of the inherent powers by the court so long as it deems it necessary to prevent any injustice or any abuse of its own process. It follows that where the rules contain provisions making available sufficient remedies, the court will not invoke its inherent powers . (Emphasis added.)

Similarly, in Nainsingh v Koonwarjee
AIR 1970 SC 997
, Hedge J when commenting on the inherent powers of s 151 of the Indian Civil Procedure Code which is of similar effect to our O 92 r 4 of the
Rules of the High Court 1980 stated as follows:

Inherent jurisdiction of the court must be exercised subject to the rule that if the Code does contain specific provisions which would meet the necessities of the case, such provisions should be followed and inherent jurisdiction should not be invoked. In other words, the court cannot make use of the special provisions of s 151 of the Code where a party had his remedy provided elsewhere in the Code and he neglected to avail himself of the same. Further, the power under s 151 of the Code cannot be exercised as an appellate power.

Some 10 years earlier, the Indian Supreme Court had already ruled that the powers saved by s 151 are not powers over substantive rights and in Padam Sen v State of UP
AIR 1961 SC 218
at p 219 , the court in a similar vein expressed that:

The inherent powers of the court are in addition to the powers specifically conferred on the court by the Code. They are complementary to those powers and therefore it must be held that the court is free to exercise them for the purposes mentioned in s 151 of the Code when the exercise of those powers is not in any way in conflict with what has been expressly provided in the Code or against the intentions of the Legislature. It is also well recognized that the inherent power is not to be exercised in a manner which will be contrary to or different from the procedure expressly provided in the Code.

In my opinion, the inherent powers of the court as provided under O 92 r 4 of the
Rules of the High Court 1980 must not only be exercised subject to other express provision of the Rules but it must also not be in conflict with the intention of the legislature to be found within the Rules or other substantive legislation.

In our present case, the express procedure to be adopted in an application for certiorari, ie to call for the records and quash the tribunal's order appear ostensibly on the face of O 53 of our Rules and the deliberate intention of the legislature to exclude the High Court's powers to assess and award consequential relief either as damages or compensation, is evident from the Rule Committee's preferred election to adopt the narrower provisions of the pre-amended 1977 English Rules of the Supreme Court to those of the much wider post-amended Rules.

It is not in dispute that the Industrial Court had come to the positive decision that the appellant had been 'dismissed with just cause and excuse'. If that finding is to be transposed into a negative sense, that is to say, without just cause and excuse this court will have to reverse the Industrial Court's decision. Such a reversal, can only be implemented by the exercise of appellate jurisdiction – the type of jurisdiction which the court does not possess in a Judicial Review and a principle which has been settled by a long line of decisive authorities. The consequential effect to this course of action is to render the assessment and award of compensation to the appellant by the court to be an act clearly in excess of the court's jurisdiction.

It has been suggested in the majority judgment that the appellant's personal hardship and the need for exigent remedy are sufficient reasons for this court not to take the normal course of sending this case back to the Industrial Court for a retrial but in lieu of that to proceed with the Award for consequential relief.

With respect, I am unable to agree. The appellant – or in any event, his counsel – must have been aware of the two courses of action open to the appellant, ie to resort to the remedy by reference to the High Court under
s 33A of the Industrial Relations Act 1967 or to quash the Industrial Court's order under certiorari. He chose the latter and so should be satisfied with the resulting remedy obtainable from his own choice.

We have been continually reminded – and indeed, this is also the rationale in the judgment or the granting of consequential relief – that the appellant had to wait for a long time for the remedy and this period, it was said, could go on even longer if we were to remit the case for a retrial. The answer is obvious. If the appellant had to wait for seven years to obtain his remedy, that delay is not the result of defective legislation but possibly the outcome of a sluggish judiciary.

The legislature in its own wisdom has enacted the
Industrial Relations Act 1967 which provides for a specialized tribunal to deal with that particular relationship existing between employers and their employees and in respect thereto has prescribed the mode of settling any disputes that could arise between them. It is apparent from s 33(4) of the Act, that Parliament had intended, and it has also been judicially recognized, that the tribunal should be the final arbiter at least on question of facts. On the question of law, the judiciary has progressively maintained that it has, through the power of Judicial Review, the powers to exercise supervisory but not appellate jurisdiction. The nature of the supervisory power and the exclusion of appellate jurisdiction are to be found in various legislations, such as the
Industrial Relations Act 1967 , the
Courts of Judicature Act 1964 , the
Rules of the High Court 1980 and a multitude of undisputed judicial precedents. Under such circumstances, is it wise for us to invoke the rules of interpretation or the use of inherent powers to bring the general purpose of the law into line with some special circumstances.

Perhaps the following words of Lord Diplock in the House of Lords case of Duport Steels Ltd & Ors v Sirs & Ors
[1980] 1 WLR 142 at p 157
could provide some guidelines to our judicial conscience:

… When Parliament legislates to remedy what the majority of its members at the time perceive to be a defect or a lacuna in the existing law (whether it be the written law as it has been expounded by the judges in decided cases), the role of the judiciary is confined to ascertaining from the words that Parliament has approved as expressing its intention what that intention was, and to giving effect to it. Where the meaning of the statutory words is plain and unambiguous it is not for the judges to invent fancied ambiguities as an excuse for failing to give effect to its plain meaning because they themselves consider that the consequences of doing so would be inexpedient, or even unjust or immoral. In controversial matters such as are involved in industrial relations there is room for differences of opinion as to what is expedient, what is just and what is morally justifiable. Under our constitution, it is Parliament's opinion on these matters that is paramount.

A statute passed to remedy what is perceived by Parliament to be a defect in the existing law may in actual operation turn out to have injurious consequences that Parliament did not anticipate at the time the statute was passed; if it had, it would have made some provision in the Act in order to prevent them. It is at least possible that Parliament when the Acts of 1974 and 1976 were passed did not anticipate that so widespread and crippling use as has in fact occurred would be made of sympathetic withdrawals of labour and of secondary blacking and picketing in support of sectional interests able to exercise 'industrial muscle.' But if this be the case it is for Parliament, not for the judiciary , to decide whether any changes should be made to the law as stated in the Acts, and, if so, what are the precise limits that ought to be imposed upon the immunity from liability for torts committed in the course of taking industrial action. These are matters on which there is a wide legislative choice the exercise of which is likely to be influenced by the political complexion of the government and the state of public opinion at the time the amending legislation is under consideration.

It endangers continued public confidence in the political impartiality of the judiciary, which is essential to the continuance of the rule of law, if judges, under the guise of interpretation, provide their own preferred amendments to statutes which experience of their operation has shown to have had consequences that members of the court before whom the matter comes consider to be injurious to the public interest.

I would readily agree that inherent powers as contained in O 92 r 4 are indispensible implements for use of the courts to prevent injustice or any abuse of the process of the court. But the powers themselves stand to be abused if they were to be exercised without circumspection by the courts. For myself, I would undoubtedly use them in cases where Parliament has omitted to provide in the Act something so glaring which obviously ought to have been there. But on no account should these powers be used to defeat the intention of the legislature, especially so when it has deliberately excluded the use of such particular remedy from any legislation.

With regret, I am unable to concur with an interpretation that could alter a particular course of justice as enacted by Parliament and in doing so reduce the pronounced principle of supervisory jurisdiction in a long line of judicial precedents, nugatory.
For the aforesaid reasons, I hold that the court has no jurisdiction to proceed to hear and award compensation after the Industrial Court's order had been quashed.
I would therefore confirm our order to quash the Industrial Court's Award but remit the matter for retrial before that Court.

As an epilogue, I would like to place on record that if I have overstated my views I trust that I would be forgiven. This judgment is written with no other motive than a sincere desire to uphold an entrenched principle of the law on Judicial Review. Dissenting judgments appear to be a rare exception to our judicial lifestyle in these days, but nevertheless judges should not feel unduly troubled in stating honestly their dissenting views even if they stand in the smallest minority, lest they could be denounced for practising intellectual dishonesty in arriving at their decisions. Speaking for myself, I would say that dissenting judgments are the surest indication of an honest, independent and alert judiciary.

Some twelve days after the three separate judgments of the members of this court had been read out in Open Court by the Registrars concerned on 20 July 1996, I had had the advantage of reading the elaborate dissenting judgment of Wan Yahya FCJ, but, with profound respect, find myself unable to agree with his conclusions and shall now endeavour to explain why, though not necessarily in the same order as they appear in the dissenting judgment.

Nearer home, in Collector of Land Revenue, Johore Bahru v South Malaysia Industries Bhd
[1978] 1 MLJ 130 at p 134
, HRH Sultan Azlan Shah (Raja Azlan Shah FJ as he then was) found it necessary to write a supplementary judgment dated 5 January 1978 to repair an omission in his principal judgment dated 25 August 1977, on an important point of law as to the jurisdiction of the court to entertain an application for relief against forfeiture under s 237 of the National Land Code.

In the present context, it is worth noting that there is the additional factor that the judgments of this court are not subject to appeal and so there can be no question of a losing party being prejudiced by a supplementation to a judgment.
I must now explain why I find myself unable to agree with the conclusions in the dissenting judgment.

Firstly, the dissenting judgment has laid much stress on the provisions of the proviso to
s 25(2) of the Courts of Judicature Act 1964 ('the proviso to s 25(2)') which reads:
Provided that all such powers shall be exercised in accordance with any written law or rules of court relating to the same.

It argues that the proviso to s 25(2) is restrictive and specifies the
Rules of the High Court 1980 , to which s 25(2) is subject. It points out that under O 53 of the
Rules of the High Court 1980 , our courts are only empowered in appropriate circumstances, to grant the usual prerogative orders, for example, it can quash an impugned order and, if necessary, send the matter back to the inferior court or tribunal or other authority for re-hearing, but nothing more.

The dissenting judgment further argues, that although in the United Kingdom, since the introduction in 1977 of the new
O 53 of the Rules of the Supreme Court, the courts there are empowered to grant a declaration or an injunction or damages or a combination of these remedies yet, in this country, we had opted for the pre-1977 United Kingdom O 53 which did not provide for the grant of such reliefs. The effect of this, so the dissenting judgment says, is that the most this court can do, in the present case, is to quash the Award of the Industrial Court and remit the case to the Industrial Court to hear and determine the question whether the Employee had been dismissed from service for just cause or excuse and, if it should conclude that the dismissal was wrongful, to decide on the appropriate reliefs to be Awarded whether by ordering reinstatement or payment of compensation. Therefore, as regards this part of the case, the dissenting judgment concludes that this court has no jurisdiction to find that the Employee was dismissed from service without just cause or excuse or to grant the consequential orders prayed for by counsel for the Employee.

By way of preliminary, there are a few general observations I should like to make regarding the effect of a proviso. As Latham CJ said in Minister of State for the Army v Dalziel
(1944) 68 CLR 261 at p 274
:

As a general rule, a proviso should not be interpreted as if it were a substantive provision independent of the provisions to which it is a proviso. Speaking generally, a proviso is a provision which is 'dependent on the main enactment' and not an 'independent enacting clause': cf R v Dibdin
[1910] P 57 at 125
.
And, as DC Pearce and RS Geddes have observed in their admirable book, Statutory Interpretation in Australia (3rd Ed):

… it may be that a proviso was inserted out of abundant caution to make it perfectly clear that a section is not to apply in certain circumstances or to certain persons when there is little doubt that it would not have done so anyway. … The proviso may only have been intended to be declaratory of the intention of the section: Bretherton v United Kingdom Totalisator Co Ltd
[1945] KB 555 at p 561
.
In my view, this was, the purpose of the proviso to s 25(2); it is intended simply to make clear the meaning of what has gone before in the enacting clause.

Most importantly, it is obvious that the provisions of the proviso to s 25(2) do not affect the powers of the court referred to in para 1 of the Schedule to the
Courts of Judicature Act 1964 ('the Schedule'); they merely control their exercise by stipulating that they shall be exercised in accordance with any written law or rules of court relating to the same. These requirements, in my view, would be silently implied in s 25(2) even without the proviso.

Next, in my view, the words 'in accordance with any written law', are the equivalent of 'not repugnant tO', 'not in conflict with' or 'not inconsistent with statute law'. It follows that recourse may be had to para 1 of the Schedule to derive jurisdiction to grant the reliefs specified therein unless there is explicit statutory prohibition. As Gopal Sri Ram JCA has pointed out in Hong Leong Equipment Sdn Bhd v Liew Fook Chuan
[1996] 1 MLJ 481 at p 542
, this was the approach adopted by the then Federal Court in Zainal Abidin v Century Hotel
[1982] 1 MLJ 260
, when it had relied on para 6 of the Schedule to derive Mareva jurisdiction. I know of no written law which prohibits us from making the orders we had made in this case.

Similarly, turning to the words 'in accordance with … rules of court relating to the same', all these words mean is that the procedure to move an application for the prerogative orders shall be in accordance with the requirements of O 53. There was no dispute that, in this case, there was before the High Court, an application for Judicial Review which complied with the procedure prescribed by O 53, seeking to quash the Award of the Industrial Court.

The next topic to be logically considered in this context, is the status of the
Rules of the High Court 1980 .

By s 17(1) of the
Courts of Judicature Act 1964 , powers are conferred upon the Rules Committee to make 'rules of court' for the purpose of regulating and prescribing the practice and procedure to be followed in the respective courts for which each of them is constituted but within the strict limits defined by s 16.

The most decisive limitation placed on the powers of the Rules Committee, and indeed on other rule-making authorities, is that they extend to regulating the 'practice and procedure' of the High Court and other courts for which the Rules are made. Although these powers are wide, yet it cannot be gainsaid, that they do not extend into the area of substantive law . Clearly, there is a vital distinction made between, on the one hand, substantive law, the function of which is to define, create, confer or impose legal rights and duties, and on the other hand, procedural law, the function of which is to provide the machinery, the manner or means, by recourse to which legal rights and duties may be enforced or recognized by courts of law or any other tribunal seized with jurisdiction to adjudicate on a dispute before it.

I am fortified in the view I take regarding the legal status of the
Rules of the High Court 1980 by the following passages in 37 Halsbury's Laws (4th Ed) para 10:

The Rules of the Supreme Court are, a form of delegated or subordinate legislation, and the Supreme Court Rules Committee is empowered to make rules only within the strict limits defined by statute, whether contained in the Supreme Court Act 1981 or any other Act. The overriding limitation on the powers of the rule committee to make rules is that they must be confined to regulating and prescribing the practice and procedure to be followed in the Supreme Court, and they must not therefore extend into the area of substantive law. There is thus at the outset a vital and essential distinction between substantive law and procedural law. The function of substantive law is to define, create or confer substantive legal rights or legal status or to impose and define the nature and extent of legal duties. Everyone is entitled to enjoy such legal rights or status but equally is liable to perform or comply with his legal duties. The function of practice and procedure is to provide the machinery or the manner in which legal rights or status and legal duties may be enforced or recognized by a court of law or other recognized or properly constituted tribunal ….
And, touching on the function of the Rules of the Supreme Court, Halsbury states:

… their function is to regulate the machinery of litigation; they cannot confer to take away or alter or diminish any existing jurisdiction or any existing rights or duties. Since they are procedural in character and effect, they cannot enable an action to be brought which could not otherwise have been brought.

This leads me to make a few comments on the introduction in the United Kingdom in 1977 of the remedy of Judicial Review, when the new O 53 entirely replaced the former O 53 (upon which our O 53 is based). The scope and operation of the new Order 53 appear clearly in para 53/1–14/1 of The Supreme Court Practice (1979) at p 824. But, what is pertinent to mention, for the present purposes, is that one of the main changes introduced by the new O 53, was that it provided for the grant of a declaration or an injunction (r 1(2)) or damage (r 7) or a combination of these remedies.

Yet, it should not be overlooked, that the new O 53 was framed largely on the recommendations of the Law Commission made in their Report on Remedies in Administrative Law (Law Com No 73; Com 6407 (1976)) which clearly proposed that the reforms should be embodied in an Act of Parliament . (See eg the Lord Chancellor's Statement at 415 HL Official Report, ser 5 col 1230). It is also noteworthy that the recommendations of the Law Commission were similar to earlier procedural reforms introduced by principal legislation, in Ontario, by the Judicial Review Procedure Act 1971, and in New Zealand, by the Judicature Amendment Act 1972. See now also the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act 1977 of Australia. It is not surprising, therefore, that in the United Kingdom, statutory endorsement was given to the new remedy of Judicial Review by the Supreme Court Act 1981, so as to ensure that the new O 53, would be immune to attack or challenge as being ultra vires.

It follows, therefore, that while our O 53 can only prescribe the procedure and practice to be followed by parties when applying for Judicial Review, the source of power enjoyed by our courts to grant relief in Judicial Review proceedings is the prerogative jurisdiction inherited from the United Kingdom courts and, most importantly, para 1 of the Schedule read with
s 25 of the Courts of Judicature Act 1964. The proviso to s 25(2), and more particularly, the
Rules of the High Court 1980 , do not – and indeed cannot – narrow down or diminish or curtail the scope of the powers conferred upon our courts in Judicial Review proceedings.

With respect, therefore, it is difficult to see how the provisions of the proviso to s 25(2) can constitute an impediment to our reliance on the provisions of para 1 of the Schedule in the manner we had in this case.
So much for the proviso to s 25(2).

Secondly, the dissenting judgment has made the point that it is not open to this court to find that the Employee has been dismissed from service without just cause or excuse, as this was a question of fact for the Industrial Court by virtue of the
Industrial Relations Act 1967 .

This point appears to be supported by what Lord Brightman said in R v Hillingdon LBC, ex p Puhlhofer
[1986] AC 484 at p 518D-E
:

Where the existence or non-existence of a fact is left to the judgment and discretion of a public body and that fact involves a broad spectrum ranging from the obvious to the debatable to the just conceivable, it is the duty of the court to leave the decision of that fact to the public body to whom Parliament has entrusted the decision-making power ….

However, like most principles, there are important exceptions , which tend to blur the conceptual distinction between errors of law and fact. Two of these exceptions which are relevant to the present case must be mentioned; they are:

Reliance upon an erroneous factual conclusion may itself offend against the principles of illegality or irrationality enunciated by Lord Diplock in Council of Civil Service Unions & Ors v Minister for the Civil Service
[1985] AC 374
. Indeed, in R v Hillingdon LBC, ex p Puhllhofer
(ibid), Lord Brightman made this clear by adding to the passage in his judgment cited above, 'save in a case where it is obvious that the public body, consciously or unconsciously, are acting perversely'.

Where there is no evidence to support a conclusion, there is necessarily an error of law in the decision arrived at (see Edwards v Bairstow
[1956] AC 14
; Din (Taj) v Wandsworth LBC
, per Lord Wilberforce; R v Hillingdon LBC ex p Islam (Tafazzul)
[1983] 1 AC 688 at p 708D
, per Lord Wilberforce and at p 717G, per Lord Lowry).
But, as Wade and Forsyth Administrative Law (7th Ed, 1994) have correctly pointed out (at p 312):

'No evidence' does not mean only a total dearth of evidence. It extends to any case where the evidence, taken as a whole, is not reasonably capable of supporting the finding (see Allinson v General Council of Medical Education and Registration
[1894] 1 QB 750 at pp 760
763 ; Lee v The Showmen's Guild of Great Britain
[1952] QB 329 at p 345
), or where, in other words, no tribunal could reasonably reach that conclusion on that evidence. (See R v Roberts
[1908] l KB 407 at p 423). This 'no evidence' principle clearly has something in common with the principle that perverse or unreasonable action is unauthorized and ultra vires.

As I have said, our conclusion that the Employee had been dismissed from service without just cause or excuse was arrived at as a result of reviewing the Award not only for process but also for substance and, in my view, came within the range of the two exceptions aforesaid.

In reviewing the Award for substance , I had said, that the legal basis for this, was provided by a wealth of English case law, including those Delphic passages in the judgment of Lord Diplock in Council of Civil Service Unions & Ors v Minister for the Civil Service
(ibid) dealing with what I referred to as his ' other grounds ' of review, namely, 'illegality' and 'irrationality' and possibly 'proportionality'. I had also referred to the decision of the Indian Supreme Court in Ranjit Thakur v Union of India
AIR 1987 SC 2386
showing the reach and extent of the review jurisdiction of the courts in that country.

The matter, however, did not rest there, because as I had said, in my supporting judgment, the jurisdiction of our courts to grant any of the prerogative orders flows not only from the prerogative jurisdiction inherited from the courts in the United Kingdom but, most importantly, from the provisions of para 1 of the Schedule read with
s 25 of the Courts of Judicature Act 1964 which confer on our courts far wider powers than those enjoyed by the courts in the United Kingdom.

I must next touch on the words 'for the enforcement of the rights conferred by Part II of the Constitution, or any of them, or for any purpose' appearing in para 1 of the Schedule. The word 'enforcement' is significant from the point of view of whether we had jurisdiction to find that the Employee had been dismissed from service without just cause or excuse and to make the consequential orders aforesaid.

In R v Bates
[1982] 2 NSWLR 894 at p 895
, Samuels JA had to consider the meaning of the word 'enforced' and said:
The relevant meaning assigned in the Shorter Oxford English Dictionary is that 'to enforce' means 'to compel observance of'. That I think is the ordinary meaning.

In my view, this is the meaning applicable to the word 'enforcement' in para 1 of the Schedule. That is precisely what I had done when I found that the Employee had been dismissed from service without just cause or excuse and made the consequential orders concerned; I was compelling observance of the right to livelihood which is one of the fundamental rights under Pt II of the Constitution.

My view, that the provisions of para 1 of the Schedule, are to be accorded a broad and liberal treatment, is reinforced by the following observations of Gopal Sri Ram JCA, when speaking for the majority in Hong Leong Equipment Sdn Bhd v Liew Fook Chuan
[1996] 1 MLJ 481
.
First of all, by way of preliminary, his Lordship said this (at pp�541H—542G):

I now turn to consider the second and perhaps wider basis of the High Court's power in the field of public law remedies. It is para 1 of the Schedule to the
Courts of Judicature Act 1964 ('the Schedule') which reads as follows:

'Power to issue to any person or authority directions, orders or writs, including writs of the nature of habeas corpus, mandamus, prohibition, quo warranto and certiorari, or any others for the enforcement of the rights conferred by Part II of the Constitution, or any of them, or for any purpose.'

The powers conferred by the Schedule upon a High Court are, according to its terms, 'additional powers', that is to say, powers in addition to those already seized of by that court. Resort may therefore be had to paragraphs in the Schedule to found jurisdiction to grant relief not expressly prohibited by written law. This is precisely the approach taken by the Federal Court in Zainal Abidin v Century Hotel
[1982] 1 MLJ 260
, where it relied upon para 6 of the Schedule to found the Mareva jurisdiction.

Now, it is settled law that a schedule to a legislative enactment is part of that enactment, and falls to be construed according to its own language and purpose. This approach to the interpretation of schedules to Acts of Parliament appears in the judgment of Roper CJ (Eq) in Re Foley
(1952) 53 SR (NSW) 31
at p 36 :

'The schedule itself, however, is a legislative enactment and is not necessarily wholly constrained by the section of the Act which introduces it, or by its own heading. The principles which ought to be applied in its construction are those set out by Lord Sterndale MR in IR Commrs v Gittus
[1920] 1 KB 563 at p 576
:

'It seems to me that there are two principles or rules of interpretation which ought to be applied to the combination of Act and Schedule. If the Act says that the schedule is to be used for a certain purpose and the heading of the part of the schedule in question shows that it is prima facie at any rate devoted to that purpose, then you must read the Act and the schedule as though the schedule were operating for that purpose, and if you can satisfy the language of the section without extending it beyond that purpose you ought to do it. But if inspite of that you find in the language of the schedule words and terms that go clearly outside that purpose, then you must give effect to them and you must not consider them as limited by the heading of that part of the schedule or by the purpose mentioned in the Act for which the schedule is prima facie to be used. You cannot refuse to give effect to clear words simply because prima facie they seem to be limited by the heading of the schedule and the definition of the purpose of the schedule contained in the Act . (Emphasis added).'
It is, therefore, of paramount importance for a court to have regard to the particular words used by para 1 of the Schedule, and to give them such effect as would advance their intent and purpose.
Next, drawing attention to the nature and amplitude of the remedies contemplated by para 1 of the Schedule, his Lordship said this (at pp 543D—544A):

…, it is to be noted that the paragraph primarily deals with public law concepts and public law remedies. The reference to 'any authority', which is a term commonly used in public law, and to the remedies of 'habeas corpus, mandamus, prohibition, quo warranto and certiorari', all of which are public law remedies, reasonably supports this view.

…, it is plain that Parliament intended that the High Court should be empowered to grant relief which is ordinarily beyond the scope of the usual public law remedies. That intention finds expression in the word 'including' which has been interposed between the phrase 'directions, orders or writs' and the phrase 'writs of the nature of habeas corpus, mandamus, prohibition, quo warranto and certiorari, or any others'. So too, the phrase 'or for any other purpose', with which the paragraph concludes, makes clear the wide area in which the remedies are to operate. These matters, in my judgment, reflect the conferment of a wide power upon the High Court in the matter of public law remedies.

Consequently, the power of the High Court in the field of public law remedies is not confined to the grant of usual prerogative orders known to English law. Our courts should not consider themselves to be fettered by those antiquated shackles of restrictive traditionalism which the common law of England has imposed upon itself. They are at liberty to develop a common law that is to govern the grant of public law remedies based upon our own legislation. They may, of course, be guided by the decisions of courts of a jurisdiction which has an analogous provision. But ultimately, they must hearken to the provisions of our own written law when determining the nature and scope of their powers.

In my judgment, the wide power conferred by the language of para 1 of the Schedule enables our courts to adopt a fairly flexible approach when they come to decide upon the appropriate remedy that is to be granted in a particular case.

The relief they are empowered to grant is by no means to be confined within any legal straightjacket. The are at liberty to fashion the appropriate remedy to fit the factual matrix of a particular case, and to grant such relief as meets the ends of justice.
Then, to illustrate, his Lordship said this (at pp 544A—C):

Assume for a moment that an Award of the Industrial Court upholding the dismissal of a workman is quashed by certiorari. The ordinary course – and this is the course that would be taken by an English court – would be to remit the matter to the Industrial Court by way of mandamus to compel it to rehear the case. But the resultant delay and the inevitable result in the workman's favour may well be compelling factors to justify the Award of relief by the High Court.

In a proper case, I envisage no impediment to the High Court making the appropriate determination and Awarding fair compensation to the workman. In such cases, it is difficult to see what possible good could come out of prolonging the agony of the parties to the dispute by delaying the matter and adding to the cause list of an already overworked tribunal.

Thus, it was my view, that in appropriate circumstances, our High Courts have the power not merely to quash an Award of the Industrial Court but to go on to make a finding that an employee has been dismissed from service without just cause or excuse, and when necessary, to award fair compensation. Consequently, on appeal from the judgment of the High Court to this court, we too, as an Apex Court, with full appellate powers, must have the same power.

In any event, reflection reveals that on a further ground also we were empowered not merely to quash the Award of the Industrial Court but also to make a finding that the Employee had been dismissed from service without just cause or excuse, and to go on to make the consequential orders for fair compensation.

The present appeal from the judgment of the High Court was brought by a notice of appeal dated and filed on 6 January 1994, and lay directly to the Supreme Court (the predecessor of this court) by reason of the provisions of
s 67(1) of the Courts of Judicature Act 1964, in the form that it took prior to its amendment on 24�June 1994, by the Courts of Judicature (Amendment) Act 1994 (Act A886)
s 16(b) , when the words 'Court of Appeal' were substituted for the words 'Supreme Court'.

It follows that the powers exercisable by this Court when hearing this appeal from the judgment of the High Court would, by reason of
s 30 of the Interpretation Acts 1948 and 1967 (Consolidated and Revised – 1989), be the powers provided for by
sub-s (4) of s 69 of the Courts of Judicature Act 1964 in the form that it took prior to its amendment on 24 June 1994 by the Courts of Judicature (Amendment) Act 1994 (Act A886)
s 16(b) when the words 'Court of Appeal' was substituted for the words 'Supreme Court', which gives this court power not only to make any order which ought to have been made but also to 'make such further or other order as the case may require '. (See eg S ungei Biak Tin Mines Ltd v Saw Choo Theng & Anor
[1970] 2 MLJ 226
).
Rule 51(4) of the Rules of the Supreme Court 1980, (in pari materia with
sub-s (4) of s 69 of the Courts of Judicature Act 1964 in the form that it took prior to its amendment aforesaid) and applicable to the present appeal by reason of r 138 of the Federal Court Rules 1995, points to the same conclusion. These powers are sufficient to enable us to find that the Employee had been dismissed from service without just cause or excuse and to make the consequential orders for fair compensation.
So much for our powers. The next topic to be logically considered is the exercise of those powers.
It will be recalled that before the High Court, the Award of the Industrial Court was challenged not only for process but also for substance as being manifestly perverse.

To recapitulate, the case for the Employee at all levels, in effect, was that the act of the Employer in terminating his services by the letter dated 20 April 1988, although ostensibly in pursuance of a retrenchment exercise was really a device to cloak a mala fide exercise of power or, in other words, an act of victimization, thus avoiding a fair enquiry into certain baseless allegations of misconduct which the Employer had no intention of pursuing. Indeed, the learned Judge in the High Court had found that the Employer had decided to give the Employee the benefit of the doubt regarding them. In other words, the case for the Employee was that this was not a redundancy situation at all; the letter of termination was really a cover up for the Employer's inability to establish those allegations by fair enquiry and the ulterior purpose of the exercise was to get rid of the Employee because 'he was an evil to be eliminated'. Counsel for the Employee relied on the Indian Supreme Court decision of L Michael & Anor v M/s Johnson Pumps India Ltd
[1975] 1 LLJ 262
to support this point.
At this stage, I should like to pray in aid certain findings which appear in the dissenting judgment.

In the first place, the dissenting judgment accepts that the Industrial Court had misunderstood the Employee's case, and 'that the issues raised by the Employee were very pertinent and if accepted by the court, it would have negated the Employer's claim that termination was due to redundancy' (see p 199B of the dissenting judgment).

In the second place, the dissenting judgment concludes, as regards this part of the case, 'the failure of the Industrial Court to consider the issue raised by the appellant amounts to a serious error of fact and law which affected the jurisdiction of that court'. (see p 199H of the dissenting judgment).

In the third place, the dissenting judgment 'fully supports the first part of the Chief Justice's judgment and the order to quash the decision of the Industrial Court'. (See p 200B of the dissenting judgment).
I must now direct attention to the present proceedings.

Before us, on the first day of the hearing on 22 March 1995, the whole of the material evidence appearing in the record of appeal (which included the entire proceedings in the High Court and the Industrial Court) relevant to the issue of whether the Employee had been dismissed from service for just cause or excuse, was examined by counsel for the Employee with some care and it is unnecessary to discuss it again.

Suffice it to say that counsel for the Employee had, inter alia, cogently argued that although there was before the High Court an affidavit of the Employee (pp 57/63 of the record of appeal) containing substantial particulars of the alleged circumstances leading up to the letter of termination aforesaid, and claiming that the decision of the Industrial Court that the Employee had been dismissed from service for just cause or excuse was, by reason thereof, 'patently erroneous and manifestly perverse', yet it had not been contradicted by the Employer by counter affidavit, with the result that its contents are deemed to be admitted. Counsel for the Employer, Mr Karthegesu (Dr Das not having yet been retained), did not respond to this submission.
With due respect, I must also add that nowhere in the dissenting judgment has this important submission been mentioned which leaves me with the impression that it has been overlooked.
Now, at an application for Judicial Review, evidence is normally presented in the form of affidavits. I must therefore touch on the appreciation of affidavit evidence in Judicial Review proceedings.

In England, the Divisional Court labours under no inherent disability to resolve disputed facts. The observation that Judicial Review process is unsuitable for resolving factual disputes ought not, therefore, to be overstated.
In the book entitled Judicial Review by Michael Supperstone QC and James Goudie QC, under the topic of 'Evidence', I find the following passage (at p 378):

The fact that evidence is given by affidavit does not mean that the court is unwilling or unable to resolve any disputes of fact that should arise. Where there is a conflict of evidence on the affidavits, but the probabilities can be shown to favour one account over the other, the court can act on that factual footing.

In this, I think, the authors are correct. I note, for example, in Chief Constable of North Wales Police v Evans
[1982] 1 WLR 1155
, HL, there was a 'conflict of evidence as to the interview', as to which, on appeal to the House of Lords, Lord Bridge (at p 1165F) preferred Evans's version 'on the probabilities'. So also, in Leech v Deputy Governor of Parkhurst Prison
[1988] AC 533
, the ability to resolve factual disputes was a central point of the rejection of R v Deputy Governor of Camphill Prison, ex p King
[1985] QB 735
.

In India, there is authority for saying that in Judicial Review proceedings, the court is inclined to hold that the normal rule of pleadings applies, so that it is necessary that material averments of fact in the return, must either affirm or deny the allegations made in the affidavit filed in support of the petition, and such averments, if not denied in the return, must be taken to have been accepted. (See eg Ramarao Laxmikant Shirkhedkar v Accountant General Maharashtra
AIR 1963 Bom 121
.) Similarly, the Supreme Court decision in Rowjee v State of AP
AIR 1964 SC 962
, shows that in such proceedings a material averment in the affidavit filed in support of the petition, alleging that those in power were motivated by bias and personal ill-will against the petitioner, which is not traversed by respondents by counter-affidavit giving their version of the denial, must be taken as admitted. Other authorities on the need for counter-affidavits by persons having personal knowledge of the facts, where there are allegations of mala fides are: Pratap Singh v State of Punjab
AIR 1964 SC 72
; Narayan v State of AP
AIR 1971 SC 1716
and MP Industries v Income Tax Officer Nagpur
AIR 1970 SC 1011
.

To recapitulate, the importance of the allegations by the Employee as to the circumstances surrounding the purported termination of his services was rightly recognized in the dissenting judgment where it is conceded that '– there were ample allegations of biasness, victimization and previous attempts to terminate the claimant's service through charges of misconduct, …' which allegations '… if accepted by the court – would have negated the Employer's claim that termination was due to redundancy.' Indeed, the allegations if accepted, would show that the purported termination was so unreasonable that it might be described as being done in bad faith. (See Associated Provincial Picture Houses v Wednesbury Corp
[1948] 1 KB 223 at p 229
, per Greene MR and L Michael & Anor v M/s Johnson Pumps Ltd
[1975] 1 LLJ 262
).

But, with respect, what appears to have been overlooked in the dissenting judgment is the contention of counsel for the Employee that these allegations made on affidavit which were most material had not been contradicted by counter-affidavit on behalf of the Employer and are deemed to be admitted. To hold contrary to this contention, would have been to fly in the face of the uncontroverted affidavit evidence. Once these allegations are deemed admitted, as they undoubtedly should have been, I fail to see what useful purpose would be served by remitting the case to the Industrial Court to determine the question whether the Employee's dismissal from service was for just cause or excuse. In such a situation, involving as it does a man's livelihood, he should not be exposed to the hazard, anxiety and delay of proceedings before a freshly constituted tribunal and, thus, to the risk of misapplication of the law.

In any event, at the end of the argument, regarding this part of the case, I was satisfied, upon the whole of the evidence appearing in the record of appeal, that the Award of the Industrial Court was flawed on the grounds of Wednesbury unreasonableness and that the Employee had been dismissed from service without just cause or excuse; in other words, wrongfully. The appeal was then allowed.

It was at this stage that counsel for the Employee raised the question of consequential orders for the payment of compensation for our consideration, whereupon, counsel for the Employer, Mr Karthegesu, objected saying that we had no jurisdiction to decide this question and adding that he needed more time to prepare this part of the case. I also seem to recall that Mr Karthegesu indicated that he might want to retain the services of a leading counsel. We granted his request and the appeal was thereupon adjourned to a date ten days later.

When hearing of the appeal resumed, the Employer had the advantage of the services of eminent counsel Dr CV Das and Mr Karthigesu as junior counsel. The Employee continued to be represented by DatO' Lingam. At the conclusion of the arguments, we had reserved judgment.

As I had said in my supporting judgment, it appeared that all the material evidence for the purpose of assessing the monetary compensation payable was before us, and indeed, there was no suggestion to the contrary by learned counsel for the Employer, Dr Das. Had there been such a suggestion, then no doubt, we would have had to consider whether or not to remit the matter to the Industrial Court with a direction to assess the compensation payable. But, in the event, all that appeared to be required was a simple arithmetical calculation and this was why I concluded: 'In the very special circumstances of the case, to remit the case to the Industrial Court to assess the monetary compensation payable by the Employer to the Employee would seem to be a certain detachment from reality and, more importantly, it will not answer the needs of justice.'

Thirdly, the dissenting judgment has also made the point that it was inappropriate for us to have made the consequential orders concerned, because before the Industrial Court, the Employee had prayed for reinstatement; so the question whether he should be reinstated or paid compensation, was a question of fact for the determination of the Industrial Court, and not this court. In carrying out that function, the Industrial Court would have to exercise a discretion, regard being had to all the evidence before it and not just the affidavit evidence. This, the dissenting judgment argues, affords a further ground why we should have refrained from making the consequential orders concerned.
