With respect, this criticism overlooks the point that before us, on the question of consequential reliefs, counsel for the Employee had confined his contention to compensation. Therefore, no other order except that of compensation would have been appropriate and so reinstatement ceased to be an issue.

Fourthly, the dissenting judgment has made the point that it would be wrong for us to derive analogical support from Indian cases on Art 226 of the Indian Constitution for two reasons: (1) no opportunity had been accorded by this court to counsel for the Employer to argue this point, and (2) in any event, the provisions of Art 226 and our para 1 of the Schedule are materially different.

As to point (1): this criticism overlooks the fact that although counsel for the Employee, did not in the course of his argument before us specifically refer to Art 226, he had in his bundle of authorities, a copy of which had been served on his opponent, included a number of Indian decisions on employment law, one of which at least – L Michael v M/s Johnson Pumps Ltd
[1975] 1 LLJ 262
, referred to without disapproval by our old Federal Court in Dr A Dutt v Assunta Hospital
[1981] 1 MLJ 304 at 312
– contains a cited extract wherein specific reference is made to Art 226. Moreover, during the argument, counsel for the Employee had cited the case of L�Michael in support of his plea of 'victimization' (see p 228G—I). This should have been sufficient to put counsel for the Employer on notice, regarding the Art 226 point. It is therefore difficult to see how it could be said that counsel for the Employer was deprived of the opportunity of dealing with the Art 226 point and generally with regard to the applicability of Indian decisions.

In these circumstances, for myself, I regret I cannot agree that the observations of their Lordships of the Privy Council in the Hong Kong Privy Council case of Hoe Cheong Products Co Ltd v Cargill Hong Kong Ltd
[1995] 1 WLR 404
, reproduced in the dissenting judgment, have any bearing on this part of the case.

In any event, in that case, the Court of Appeal of Hong Kong had decided the appeal on an entirely new question of law not raised by the parties as to which there had been insufficient exploration of the facts at the trial to enable the new point to be taken. The situation in the present appeal is totally different.

Here, the purely legal question was whether analogical support could be derived from Art 226 and the Indian cases decided thereon, for the purpose of assisting in the determination of a fiercely contested issue concerning the extent of the jurisdiction of our High Courts in the field of public law remedies. This question of analogical support was by way of make weight only and not therefore a decisive factor upon which the result of the appeal depended. It also required no exploration of the facts.

As to point (2), this raises the question whether our para 1 of the Schedule is equivalent to the Indian Art 226. In my view, the law on this point and the consequences which flow from it, have been correctly stated by Gopal Sri Ram JCA in Hong Leong Equipment Sdn Bhd v Liew Fook Chuan
[1996] 1 MLJ 481
.

First of all, his Lordship drew attention to analogous law both in the United Kingdom and in India, and expressed the opinion that our para 1 of the Schedule was equivalent to Art 226 of the Indian Constitution and, that therefore, Indian case law was entitled to greater weight than case law from the United Kingdom or other common law countries (at pp 542H—543C) where there was no equivalent provision. This is how he put it:

… it is to be noted that the paragraph is not based upon or drawn from any United Kingdom statute. The United Kingdom's Supreme Court Act 1981 has no provision that bears close resemblance to para l. The paragraph is, however, in pari materia with Art 226(1) of the Indian Constitution which reads as follows:

'Notwithstanding anything in Art 32, every High Court shall have power, throughout the territories in relation to which it exercises jurisdiction, to issue to any person or authority, including in appropriate cases any Government, within those territories, directions, orders or writs including writ in the nature of habeas corpus, mandamus, prohibition, qua warranto and certiorari, or any of them, for the enforcement of any of the right conferred by Part III and for any other purpose .'

For completeness, I would add that Pt II of the Federal Constitution which contains the fundamental liberties guaranteed by the supreme law, and which finds mention in para 1 of the Schedule, is the equivalent of Pt III of the Indian Constitution.

It follows that, because of the close resemblance in the language of these two provisions – para 1 of the Schedule and Art 226 of the Indian Constitution – the decisions of Indian courts upon the analogous provision are to be accorded greater weight when determining the width of the power conferred by the paragraph, than decisions of courts in those jurisdictions where the equipollent provision is absent. These jurisdictions include England, Australia, New Zealand and Canada.

Secondly, drawing attention to the more affirmative role of the courts in India compared to their counterparts in England, in the field of public law remedies, his Lordship cited two decisions of the Supreme Court of India, in one of which the court, instead of merely quashing the order of a tribunal, and remanding the matter to the tribunal to pass a suitable order, itself passed the necessary order to avoid prolonging the dispute which might not have been fair or conducive, to the interests of parties at pp�544E—545A). This is what he said:
I notice that in the field of public law remedies, Indian courts, acting on the words of Art 226(1), have adopted a more flexible stance than their English counterparts.

In Hindustan Steel Ltd, Rourkela v Roy, AK
AIR 1970 SC 1401
, the Supreme Court of India, having quashed an order of reinstatement made by the Industrial Tribunal, went on to make an Award of compensation. The basis upon which this was done appears in the following passage in the judgment of Shelat J at p 1407 of the report:

'The question next is having held that the order of reinstatement was not a proper order, in that, it was not in consonance with the decided cases, do we simply quash the order of the Tribunal and that of the High Court and leave the concerned workman to pursue his further remedy? The other alternative would be to remand the case to the Tribunal to pass a suitable order. In either case, in view of this judgment, no other order except that of compensation can be obtained by him. If the case is remanded and the tribunal on such remand passes an order of compensation and fixes the amount, such a course would mean further proceedings and a possible appeal. That would mean prolonging the dispute, which would hardly be fair to or conducive to the interests of the parties. In these circumstances, we decided that it would be more proper that we ourselves should determine the amount of compensation which would meet the ends of justice.'

In Variety Emporium v Mohd Ibrahim
AIR 1985 SC 207
, Chandrachud CJ considered the principle to be well-settled. He said (at p 210):

'No authority is needed for the proposition that, in appropriate cases, the Court must have regard to events as they present themselves at the time when it is hearing the proceeding before it and mould the relief in the light of those events.'

The dissenting judgment has also expressed the view that unlike in India, where the power of the High Court in Judicial Review proceedings is conferred by the Constitution, to wit, Art 226, in this country, the source of such power is an ordinary Act of Parliament, to wit, the
Courts of Judicature Act 1964 , and so can be modified by another Act of Parliament, as for instance, the
Rules of the High Court 1980 .

I had, when discussing the status of the
Rules of the High Court 1980 , quoted 37 Halsbury's Laws (4th Ed) para 10, which it will be recalled, shows that although the Rules are a form of delegated legislation, 'their function is to regulate the machinery of litigation; they cannot confer or take away or alter or diminish any existing jurisdiction or any existing rights or duties'. The
Rules of the High Court 1980 cannot therefore extend into the area of substantive law and the powers of the court in Judicial Review proceedings fall within the area of substantive law, to wit, para 1 of the Schedule read with s 25.

With respect, therefore, the powers of the court under para 1 of the Schedule cannot be modified by the
Rules of the High Court 1980 . I would also, in answer, pray in aid my comments on the proviso to s 25(2) and its effect, which appear at pp 220I—224A.

Fifthly, the dissenting judgment has expressed the view that we should disregard the fact that if this matter were remitted to the Industrial Court to hear and determine the case according to law, it would entail unnecessary prolongation of proceedings, consequent delay and undue hardship to the Employee because:

it was open to the Employee to have proceeded by way of Reference under
s 33A of the Industrial Relations Act 1967, or by way of Judicial Review under O 53. Had the Employee chosen the former course, the High Court would have had full appellate powers and could by reason of sub-s (5) of s 33A 'hear and determine the question referred to it as if the reference were an appeal, and consequently, confirm, vary, substitute or quash the Award, or make such other order as it considers just or necessary'. But the Employee chose to pursue the latter course, that is, to apply for Judicial Review under O 53, and the powers of the court in such proceedings being supervisory are not as extensive as those exercised in proceedings by way of reference to the High Court on a question of law under s 33A. In other words, if there was to be undue delay, the Employee was the author of his own misfortune, and
'If the appellant had to wait for seven years to obtain his remedy, that delay is not the result of defective legislation but possibly the outcome of a sluggish judiciary'.
As to (1): This point depends for its validity on two assumptions, namely:
The powers of the High Court in the field of public law remedies in this country are limited to the extent stated in the dissenting judgment, and

The Employee was bound to have succeeded had he proceeded by way of a reference to the High Court pursuant to the provisions of
s�33A of the Industrial Relations Act 1967.
With respect, neither of the above assumptions is well-founded because:

With regard to assumption (a): The view of the majority in this case is that the powers of the High Court in the field of Public Law remedies, is not limited as aforesaid, but broad enough to have justified this Court to have made the orders that the Employee had been dismissed from service without just cause or excuse and for the payment of compensation to him.

With regard to assumption (b): It is impossible to say that had the Employee proceeded by way of a Reference under s 33A to the High Court, he was bound to have succeeded. It is axiomatic, that the prospects of success or failure in litigation can seldom, if ever, be predicted, with certainty. He may, as likely as not, have failed, and had he failed, his case would have ended in the High Court for there is no provision enabling him to take the matter further to a higher court. But having – as it turned out, wisely – elected to proceed by way of Judicial Review under O 53, and failed in the High Court, he was able to successfully take his case up to this court.

In these circumstances, it is difficult to see how the Employee could be criticized for having elected to proceed by way of Judicial Review under O 53 instead of a Reference on a question of law under s 33A. Indeed, from his point of view, it is fortunate that he did so.

Having said that, I must add that, although our High Courts are vested with broad and ample powers under para 1 of the Schedule, this is not to say, that there are no differences between their powers when hearing a Reference under
s 33A of the Industrial Relations Act 1967, as compared to an application for Judicial Review under O 53. Indeed, the differences are most material.

Unlike a reference under s 33A, Judicial Review is a discretionary jurisdiction. Each stage of the process of Judicial Review is discretionary, particularly the threshold stage of whether leave to commence proceedings will be granted, and, if granted, ultimately, whether any and, if so, what remedies, are granted.

The more obvious discretionary bars upon which the court may in the exercise of its discretion, or as a matter of evaluation, decline relief in Judicial Review proceedings, although the case may otherwise be well-grounded, are these:
that the applicant lacks sufficient interest;
that the remedy would be of no practical benefit;
having regard to (a) delay, or (b) other aspects of the applicant's conduct;
because of the effect of granting relief;
because of the availability of alternative remedies;
where the issue is the criminality or otherwise of future conduct; and
in cases of a procedural requirement not being met where the failure is 'technical' and of no practical effect.

None of the above discretionary bars applies to Reference proceedings under s 33A. However, as I have said, unlike an applicant in Judicial Review proceedings, should an applicant in a Reference under s 33A fail in the High Court, the matter ends there for there is no provision enabling him to take the matter further.

As to (2), with due respect, the remarks about 'a sluggish judiciary' being possibly the cause of delay in the disposal of cases, are open to the criticism that they amount to a mere theory unsupported by evidence, and even if true, it is difficult to see how they could be material to the point under discussion, since the Employee could hardly be blamed such delay.

Before moving on to the next point, there are some general observations I should like to make regarding the topic of hardship to the Employee caused by delay occasioned by unnecessary prolongation of proceedings.

There is a vital juridical distinction between jurisdiction and discretion. It is obvious that hardship is relevant only to the exercise of discretion and not to the question whether there is jurisdiction. It is only when the court has the jurisdiction to make an order and is considering its exercise that hardship may be a relevant consideration. We had directed ourselves accordingly.

Sixthly, the dissenting judgment has criticized reliance on the inherent jurisdiction of the High Court, of which we are reminded by
O 92 r 4 of the Rules of High Court 1980. It argues (at p 219G—H):

But the powers themselves stand to be abused if they were to be exercised without circumspection by the courts. For myself, I would undoubtedly use them in cases where Parliament has omitted to provide in the Act something so glaring which obviously ought to have been there . But on no account should these powers be used to defeat the intention of the legislature especially so when it has deliberately excluded the use of such particular remedy from any legislation. (Emphasis added.)

Whilst I entirely agree that the court is not at liberty to resort to its inherent powers in violation of a statutory provision, I regret I cannot agree with the suggestion that their use should be confined to situations where 'Parliament has omitted to provide in the Act (concerned) something so glaring which ought obviously to have been there'. In this, I am supported by the following observations by Sir Jack Jacob QC, the former Senior Master of the Supreme Court in the United Kingdom, in his article 'The Inherent Jurisdiction of the Court' [1970] Current Legal Problems 23.
Explaining the nature of inherent jurisdiction, the learned author said this (at p 24):

… The court may exercise its inherent jurisdiction even in matters which are regulated by statute or by rule of court , so long as it can do so without contravening any statutory provision…. (Emphasis added.)
The learned author then distinguished between the inherent jurisdiction and the statutory jurisdiction, as follows (at p 24):

The source of the statutory jurisdiction of the court is, of course, the statute itself, which will define the limits within which such jurisdiction is to be exercised, whereas the source of the inherent jurisdiction of the court is derived from its nature as a court of law; so that the limits of such jurisdiction are not easy to define, and indeed appear to elude definition.

The learned author then directs attention to the point that the powers conferred by the rules of court are generally additional to and not in substitution of the powers arising out of the inherent jurisdiction of the court, in these terms (at p 25):

The inherent jurisdiction of the court may be exercised in any given case, notwithstanding that there are rules of court governing the circumstances of such case . The powers conferred by rules of court are, generally speaking, additional to, and not in substitution of, powers arising out of the inherent jurisdiction of the court. The two heads of powers are generally cumulative, and not mutually exclusive, so that in any given case, the court is able to proceed under either or both heads of jurisdiction. (Emphasis added.)
Explaining the juridical basis of inherent jurisdiction, the learned author says this (at p 27):

… the jurisdiction to exercise these powers was derived, not from any statute or rule of law, but from the very nature of the court as a superior court of law, and for this reason such jurisdiction has been called 'inherent'. This description has been criticized as being 'metaphysical', but I think nevertheless that it is apt to describe the quality of this jurisdiction. For the essential character of a superior court of law necessarily involves that it should be invested with a power to maintain its authority and to prevent its process being obstructed and abused. Such a power is intrinsic in a superior court; it is its very life-blood, its very essence, its immanent attribute. Without such a power, the court would have form but would lack substance. The jurisdiction which is inherent in a superior court of law is that which enables it to fulfil itself as a court of law.
Defining inherent jurisdiction , the learned author said this (at p 51):

… the inherent jurisdiction of the court may be defined as being the reserve or fund of powers, a residual source of powers, which the court may draw upon as necessary whenever it is just or equitable to do so, and in particular to ensure the observance of the due process of law, to prevent improper vexation or oppression, to do justice between the parties and to secure a fair trial between them.
Explaining the relation between the inherent jurisdiction and rules of court , the learned author says this (at p 50):

The powers of the court under its inherent jurisdiction are complementary to its powers under rules of court; one set of powers supplements and reinforces the other. The inherent jurisdiction of the court is a most valuable adjunct to the powers conferred on the court by the rules.
And, in the next paragraph explaining the usefulness of the inherent jurisdiction, he adds (at pp 50 and 51):

On the other hand, where the usefulness of the powers under the Rules ends, the usefulness of the powers under inherent jurisdiction begins. This is shown in three important respects in which the powers arising out of the inherent jurisdiction differ from those conferred by rules of court. First, perhaps by their very nature, they are wider and more extensive powers, permeating all proceedings at all stages and filling any gaps left by the Rules and they can be exercised on a wider basis, for example, by enabling the court to admit evidence by affidavit or otherwise in order to examine all the circumstances appertaining to the merits of the case. Secondly, they can be invoked in respect of persons who are not themselves actual litigants in pending proceedings. Thirdly, they can be used to punish the offender by fine or imprisonment.

In the Singapore case of Heng Joo See v Ho Pol Ling
(Divorce Petition No 94 of 1993), Coomarasamy J put O 92 r 4 (RSC) and O 79 r 4 (SCR), (identically worded to our O 92 r 4 of the
Rules of the High Court 1980 ) in its correct perspective when he said:
… [it does] not define or give the jurisdiction …. It merely states that the Rules of Supreme Court shall not limit or affect the inherent powers which are common law powers.

The learned judge went on to accept the definition of inherent powers formulated by Sir Jack Jacob, quoted above. (See also the interesting comments by Mr Jeffrey Pinsler in his well researched work Civil Procedure at pp 18–19).

In my view, O 92 r 4 is a unique rule of court for while it neither defines nor gives jurisdiction, yet it serves as a reminder and confirmation – lest we forget – of the common law powers of the court, which are residuary or reserve powers and a separate and distinct source of jurisdiction from the statutory powers of the court.

Similarly, I have no doubt that in this country, the Court of Appeal and the Federal Court also exercise inherent jurisdiction. And lest we forget, at the risk of repetition, supervisory jurisdiction is the creature of the common law and is available in the exercise of the court's inherent power though its extent may be determined not merely by judicial development but also by legislative intervention, as for example, para 1 of the Schedule read together with
s 25 of the Courts of Judicature Act 1964.

Finally, a word or two about the 'Epilogue' in the dissenting judgment. I do unreservedly accept the laudable observation that if a judge feels strongly about not going along with the majority, then he should enter a dissent. However, the observation that dissenting judgments in the Federal Court are a rare exception these days is open to challenge. (See eg the decision of the Federal Court in Arulpragasan a/l Sandaraju v PP
[1997] 1 MLJ 1
), where the court was split 4-3; Seet Chuan Seng & Anor v Tee Yih Jia Food Manufacturing Pte Ltd
[1994] 2 MLJ 770
, where Eusoff Chin SCJ (as he then was) dissented; Chan Chin Ming & Anor v Lim Yok Eng
[1994] 3 MLJ 233
, where I dissented; Wee Choo Keong v MBf Holdings Bhd & Anor
[1995] 3 MLJ 549
, where Chong Siew Fai CJ (Sabah and Sarawak) dissented; and Pengiran Osman Shah bin Pengiran Mohd Yusof v Karam Brunai Resort Sdn Bhd & Ors
(unreported, Suit No 08-31-95) , where Wan Adnan FCJ dissented in an application for leave to appeal, to give but five recent examples offhand).

Similarly, the observation that dissenting judgments are 'the surest indication of an honest, independent and alert judiciary', is open to criticism; see, for example, RH Jackson Jin the The Supreme Court in the American System of Government (1955) at p l8:

The right of dissent is a valuable one. Wisely used on well-chosen occasions, it has been of great service to the profession and to the law. But there is nothing good, for either the court or the dissenter, in dissenting per se. Each dissenting opinion is a confession of failure to convince the writer's colleagues, and the true test of a judge is his influence in leading, not in opposing, his court.

For myself, I believe that our view on the powers of the court in Judicial Review proceedings, although they constitute a departure from previous cases decided in this country to which I have referred, is a progressive one, and in giving effect to them we derive comfort from the famous words of Denning LJ (as he then was) in his dissenting judgment in the case of Candler v Crane, Christmas & Co
[1951] 2 KB 164
, regarded by lawyers, almost without exception, as a brilliant advancement of the law of negligent misstatement, vindicated triumphantly some twenty years later in the House of Lords in Hedley Byrne & Co Ltd v Heller & Partners Ltd
[1964] AC 465
:

This argument about the novelty of the action does not appeal to me in the least. It has been put forward in all the great cases which have been milestones of progress, and it has always, or nearly always, been rejected. If you read the great cases of Ashby v White
, Parsely v Freeman
and Donoghue v Stevenson
you will find that in each of them the judges were divided in opinion. On the one side there were the timorous souls who were fearful of allowing a new cause of action. On the other side there were the bold spirits who were ready to follow it if justice so required . It was fortunate for the common law that the progressive view prevailed. (Emphasis added.)

The words of Lord Denning, although uttered in a different context, can in appropriate circumstances, serve as a guide, to a judge when an argument of novelty is put forward, as happened in the present case.
